It is not good enough on the one hand to talk about fiscal responsibility and balancing the books whilst on the other allowing government agencies to operate in a way that goes on to waste hundreds of millions of dollars of taxpayers' money.

My condemnation of the performance of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission is well known. I do not continue these statements against it out of hatred or even dislike for Aboriginal people. Anyone who has listened to what I have had to say will know that I want to abolish ATSIC because it does not work. I accept that there have been some successes that ATSIC has achieved. These have generally been small successes in the areas of cultural and artistic development. I do not wish to demean these achievements but I do ask why Australians have spent billions of dollars on Aboriginal welfare over the past 20 or 30 years to achieve outcomes many of which are worse than before the money was spent.

If ATSIC were any other government department, it would have been dragged kicking and screaming into the public eye, where its senior management would have been sacked and public accountability would have been forced. Now, to say that ATSIC should in some way perform to public expectations on expenditure of public money becomes a racist act. What better way to hide the poor performance of ministers, public servants and members of ATSIC?

I believe that there has been such an enormous waste of taxpayers' money that the public need to know what has happened. They also need to know the extent to which government, especially the Labor government, has been involved in this waste through inaction. To this end, I call upon this government to immediately set up a royal commission into the operations of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. I would like to see such a royal commission investigate all aspects of Aboriginal welfare and funding.

Calling for such a royal commission is not a racist act, though I am sure it will be reported as such by the time I finish this speech. What I want to see is an investigation to let us know what has been going on so that we can fix it. Aboriginal people and the broader Australian population deserve it. Unless we fix the way that ATSIC operates we will never see any improvement in the welfare of Aboriginal people. They will never get the support from government that they deserve as Australian citizens unless government shows the courage to treat Aborigines in the same way as it treats other Australians.

Aboriginal health is the best example of how a policy of deliberate affirmative action without responsibility has failed. It has been estimated that Australian governments have poured over $30 billion of taxpayers' funds into the Aboriginal industry since the late 1960s. Of that, $69.7 million was spent on Aboriginal health in 1994 alone.

Even one of my critics, the Governor‐General, has reported that health outcomes in many aspects are now worse than before the money was spent. How can that be? Where has the money gone? What mistakes are we making? How can we stop making these mistakes? What should we be doing instead so that we can improve the welfare of Aboriginal people? Surely these are all realistic questions that need answers. I believe that the political correctness that now passes for debate in this country has taken such a hold that a royal commission is perhaps the only way that we will get to the bottom of this issue.

But there are more aspects that need investigation than Aboriginal health. The New South Wales government's Independent Commission Against Corruption inquiry into the New South Wales Land Council has shown that over a period of many years there has been systematic incompetence, lack of accountability and evidence of substantial fraud related to Aboriginal funding. The vast majority of Aboriginal people who this money was meant for have never seen, and will never see, any benefits from it.

Whose fault is it? Was it the fault of the people who wasted the money, or of the governments who refused to put in place the proper kinds of measures to safeguard the interests of the Aborigines this money was to go to? Who are the real racists here: the people who claim that what has been happening is wrong or those who want to perpetuate it?

Many people in the Aboriginal community are just as frustrated with what is happening. Sharon Firebrace has called for a royal commission because something has to be done to stop certain leaders and factions betraying their own people. A royal commission is necessary to determine the full extent of mismanagement of services to the Aboriginal community. Beatrice Faust says that giving money to ATSIC is like carrying water in a basket.

The Aboriginal defence against greater accountability is typified by something said by Lois O'Donohue: `I ask why indigenous Australians never need to be more accountable than anyone else, for comparatively small amounts of money.' This is one of the people who have accused me of being out of touch with reality. It is demonstrably clear to anyone who will keep an open mind that in fact the standards of accountability are lower for Aboriginal people. The truth is that they should not be. We do not want an Uncle Tom mentality and not require transparency and accountability. Aborigines must take responsibility—but anyone who, like me, has stood up and insisted on equal treatment and on greater accountability is accused of racism.

Like the rest of the Australian community, Aborigines want their representatives to listen and act in the best interests of their constituents. We here in parliament know of the public's obsession with parliamentary travel expenses and accusations of travel rorts which have filled the press in recent times. We have determined that we need to be subject to special accountability to ensure that the taxpayer has a transparent view of how we spend the money given to us for these purposes, but what about ATSIC commissioners? They are paid far more than members and senators, they represent a much smaller and less diverse constituency, and yet we are not to ensure that they are also accountable for their travel expenses. We really have to get serious about this. As honourable members know, I believe that all Australians need to be treated equally. We cannot continue to fund an organisation which does not achieve the objectives for which it was set up and seeks to divide our nation.

The second aspect of my speech that I want to cover today deals with native title and Wik. I was born in this country and am proud to be an Australian. I do not like to be accused of being responsible for things that were done by other people. I was not responsible for the stolen generation, although I am genuinely sorry for those who have suffered. I know that these things did happen, but I cannot apologise to those people on behalf of others because I have no right to. I believe that it would simply add to the politicising of an issue which has been deliberately manipulated by a minority.

I am also sorry for those Aborigines who have lost access to traditional lands since colonisation, but I am opposed to any move by an intellectual elite to turn this country upside down by giving Australia back to the Aborigines. Clarrie Isaacs, who is one of my Aboriginal critics in Western Australia, actually proposes handing back 100 per cent of this country to an Aboriginal government and then having the rest of us lease it back under a crown land lease arrangement.

Recently, we have seen Aboriginal claims on more than just the land. Fishing rights in Australia are also under threat. Claims now extend over significant parts of the sea. In August last year an Elcho Islander, Mr Terry Yumbulul, said that because white Australia has been responsible for 150 years of scraping and fishing on the bottom of the sea, we should pay compensation for the loss of fish. There are 150 claims involving water—60 in Western Australia and 30 in Queensland. Who is going to pay to defend the rights of the fishing industry, and what will the effect of these claims be on investment in one of Australia's premier export industries?

I am criticised for speaking out because it is alleged I am affecting Australia's trade, an allegation made up in the minds of Australia's two great representatives, Tim Fischer and Alexander Downer. Here is another example of how Mabo and native title are destroying prospects for Australian jobs.

Another area that I wish to talk on today is the child support scheme. The child support scheme has become a very unworkable scheme. Children are being used as pawns in an often bitter and unpleasant experience which often results in the non-custodial parent being left angry and frustrated by what appears to be an arbitrary and unjust system. Those who perceive themselves as losers in the process sometimes become suicidal, depressive and vindictive. It is no coincidence that some have turned to murder or other forms of violence as a consequence.

On the other hand, some custodial parents are left with the full financial burden of raising the children of the relationship with little or no help from non‐custodial parents. In many cases, non‐custodial parents will throw in their jobs and go onto welfare to avoid paying excessive maintenance.

I would like to see the use of net wages as the basis for the calculation of child support to make the system fairer and more likely to be honoured by non‐custodial parents. Custodial parents can earn up to $42,000 before maintenance calculations are affected. If they are living in a de facto relationship, the partner's income is not taken into account. This is grossly unfair. In many instances, the maintenance‐paying parent is living in virtual poverty, while the custodial parent can afford to have a relatively higher standard of living. This was not the intent of the process in the first place.

Non‐custodial parents' wages should only be calculated on a normal working week's pay, without overtime or penalty payments being taken into consideration. If non‐custodial parents choose to have a second job, this also should not be taken into account. There should be an incentive for non‐custodial parents to feel able to reorganise their lives to take their new circumstances into account. Maintenance should not be a ticket to poverty for non‐custodial parents.

Ironically, those who do the right thing are virtually punished for their troubles, while those who walk away from their responsibilities seem to get away with it. When kids spend school holidays with non‐custodial parents, unfortunately the effect is that the parents end up paying twice because they not only pay to feed, clothe and nurture their children directly, but they are also still paying maintenance to the other parent.

It is impossible to devise a fair scheme which relies on the judgment of officers of the department who are overworked, unsympathetic and, in many cases, burnt out by the sheer volume and nature of the inquiries they are handling. This means many parents are treated in an arbitrary way which puts them under unnecessary stress and makes a difficult situation even worse.

How can you honestly expect officers under these conditions to respond in a way that can soothe the anger and frustration of parents in the system? The Australian Family Court should show more support for joint custodial arrangements because, according to research by Professor William Bender of Georgia University, children adjust much better to divorce when they are cared for in joint custody.

There are over 400,000 non‐custodial parents in the community. The government must take action and not leave the child support system in the too hard basket. The government should have a good look into the child support scheme because a lot of parents—custodial parents and non‐custodial parents—are hurting. The government must take a good look at the system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brough, Mal, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker—

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 4.50 p.m. to 5.02 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I recommence my speech proper, the first three seconds of which were absolutely brilliant, it would be remiss of me not to comment on the last point made by the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) regarding the Child Support Agency. I could comment on a number of the things she said here today, but I will not take the opportunity. In regard to the Child Support Agency, the government has had a backbench subcommittee set up for the past six months, and we have reported to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). We have already stated in the press that the government, the Prime Minister and the cabinet have made a commitment to address this problem on the Prime Minister's return from overseas and that we will endeavour, to the best of our ability, given the time constraints and the amount of legislation to go through the parliament, to have the legislation reforming the Child Support Agency come into the parliament before the end of this year.

SPEECH.PARA: I would hate to think that the member for Oxley is being an opportunist in trying, once again, to ride on the back of the fine work that has been done by the government. She tends to take credit for everything that others do and, in the meantime, merely puts up what are, in many cases, false arguments of her own. I must say, though, that some of the points she raised today are very accurate. There is obviously a lot of discontent and concern with the Child Support Agency. But, unlike the member for Oxley, this government is actually addressing the problem for the betterment of the people concerned, and particularly the children.

My purpose in rising today is to talk about the Australian inland rail expressway. Australia is a wonderful country which has many great assets: our weather, our open and clean environment, and the many rights that we enjoy here. When foreigners come to Australia, either for tourism or any other purpose, they are often struck by the enormous distances that they are faced with in travelling from one place to another. We take it in our stride, but the reality is that, for every plus that we have in being such a large, open nation, we also have the negative of the great distance and, therefore, the cost of transport of our goods and services, both to our domestic and export markets. It takes both time and money for Australia even to get its exports to the ports before they leave our shores bound for overseas markets.

The Australian inland rail is not a new idea and I certainly cannot claim it as my own. I believe it was Ben Chifley's government that first said that we did not have the money as a nation to go ahead with this project. That was after World War II, when it was decided it was needed for defence. I think that particular reason has not changed to this day. With us moving more of our troops to the north, we realise that our roads are already at capacity and that if we do not control the seaways in any time of conflict, how do we resupply ourselves? Aircraft is not the answer, given the great distances and the amount of goods that would be required to sustain any effort in the unfortunate event of us being attacked.

More immediately, we have a concern as a nation that we have export earnings being wasted because we are not competitive. There are many reasons for that, but the one that I want to focus on today is our transport cost. In my electorate, the Lockyer Valley is a small crops area where we have the potential to be part of the supermarket to Asia program, which can realise $2 billion worth of exports for Australia. Unfortunately, the cost of actually getting that product to the Asian markets in time for it to be used in a fresh state is so prohibitive that it makes that very difficult. There are some advances there. But the Australian inland rail express—which will be running from Darwin, down through Mount Isa, through central Queensland, west of the Great Divide, through the Riverina of New South Wales and finally into Victoria—can for the first time open up the west of the Great Divide and the great basin of inland Australia, which has such enormous potential.

For one example, in the mineral industry, look at Mt Isa Mines. For this company, it costs four times as much to move ore from the Mount Isa mine to the port at Townsville as it does to move their ore a comparable distance from their mines in South America. It is actually quicker and cheaper for them to use road than rail here. That is an appalling state, where we are compromising our opportunities as an export nation because of the inefficiency of our rail system and our transport system. Furthermore, by having so many trucks on the road, we do enormous damage to our infrastructure. We have also seen many fatal accidents as a result of fatigued truck drivers working incredibly long hours simply to keep Australia on the move.

This particular rail project is very visionary. It is estimated to cost somewhere in the vicinity of $10 billion. But the reason I am attracted to it is because they are not, as a consortium, asking for any federal or state government funding. I think that has been one of the reasons, from the time of Chifley, that this project has not gone ahead, because there has always been a great demand for federal and state funding. We have seen AN and its current demise. I guess that proves beyond any shadow of a doubt that governments are not the best people to run rail.

But this project we are talking about is not a conventional railway. We are talking about a railway line that can move heavy exports, heavy freight, from Melbourne to Darwin at over 160 kilometres an hour, with trains over a kilometre long. You can imagine the number of trucks that would be required to be able to move the same amount of freight. Light freight, such as fruit and vegetables, can be moved at something in the vicinity of 250 kilometres per hour. This will ensure that we can get our products to the port of Darwin, a large deepwater port which can facilitate exports to our near northern neighbours, so that we can get fresh fruit, vegetables and other produce, as well as the myriad of other exports, onto the shelves very quickly.

A few of the other benefits of this project are that we will no longer be required to tie up our southern ports to the same degree. Currently, we have many of our imports and exports travelling via the Great Barrier Reef—and we all know the dangers should there be a spill of some consequence. I believe that it is only a matter of time before something disastrous occurs on the reef, to the detriment of us all. So if we can remove that potential for damage from the reef, that is yet another benefit that this project can have.

There are also other benefits to Australia. Rather than just looking at the straight exporting of our beef, our wool and our grains, et cetera, we should also look at what has happened to the west of the Great Divide over the last 50 years. My grandparents moved from Charleville with my mother and her brother and sister approximately 50 years ago. I think it was about that time, at the end of the Second World War, when we first saw the demise of so many of these country towns; towns that were set up because of the distances in Australia. The towns were there to support the sheep stations and the cattle properties around them. But now, with the advent of very fast air travel, many property owners travel to other places to do their shopping. In Queensland they travel into Toowoomba to do their shopping. They bypass the country towns, and the very purpose of the existence of the towns no longer exists.

You cannot make an artificial reason for having these towns—you cannot manufacture a reason. There has to be a purpose for them. I believe that the inland rail will provide that purpose. It will encourage business to relocate to these areas—whether it be Dubbo or Parkes or Deniliquin or anywhere else on the Queensland route—so that they can take advantage of the open spaces, the obviously cheaper land and the very quick access to foreign ports.

I have made a promise to my whip and, being good to my word, I will keep my speech to about 10 minutes duration today due to the constraints of time. I want the House to appreciate that this is not a pipedream. People have looked at numerous projects over the years and decided that they were just too big and too unachievable. This is not just achievable; it will occur. I believe it will occur through the enterprise of private business, and that it will be running within the next decade.

Tomorrow I am attending a meeting in Sydney when a formal board will be set up and a company established. I am pleased to be able to announce that tomorrow should see KPMG begin the first revenue study to identify who can actually utilise this railway. This is a high risk venture, but I believe it will be the turning point in Australia's history. History will record its creation as the moment when Australia became a great nation and when we fulfilled our complete and total potential rather than the partial potential which we have been attempting to reach over the last two to three decades.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I commence this contribution to the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1997‐98 by making a tremendous apology. In recent times, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) has diversified his performance. These days he is a real threat, I think, to John Hinde and David Stratton and their movie critiques of Paradise Road . I understand that, at the weekend, people indicated to the minister that Glenn Close and Frances McDormand were not Australians, so he will be a real rival to these film commentators. But today in question time he made a more telling point against me: that I made the mistake of assuming that the budget expenditure on war graves overseas would do a lot more than now appears to be the case. He clarified, I have got to admit, a few days ago that the money will only be utilised in New Guinea.

SPEECH.PARA: I have got to make a dreadful apology. Whilst commending this initiative—and, as he well knows, I have written to him about war cemeteries overseas—I made the comment that the money devoted by the current government to the improvement of war cemeteries was perhaps the greatest job creation program in this budget, and that it was ironic that the jobs would be created overseas rather than in western Sydney. He is correct in saying the jobs will be created in Papua New Guinea and not in Malaysia, and I apologise for that error on my part. But I think the minister should perhaps fully concentrate on the crucial matters in this budget.

I am not disputing for one moment that commemoration is a crucial aspect of the portfolio, but bread and circuses are not the entire portfolio. Commemoration, war memorials and all these things which we all support and which have had bipartisan endorsement in this country for decades will not confuse the veterans of this country in regards to more fundamental challenges to their conditions.

It is interesting to note that many speeches these days by the minister seem, for some strange reason, to be totally preoccupied with this aspect of the budget. I want to say here today that there are deeper concerns with this portfolio than the questions of Paradise Road and how many presentations of cheques he is going to make around the country. I want to cover some aspects of that.

In regard to the overall DVA resources, the average staff numbers for the Veterans' Affairs portfolio for the 1997‐98 financial year will be cut by 610—from 3,400 down to 2,796. This includes a loss of 275 positions as a direct result of the government's imposition of an efficiency dividend for the portfolio of 14.3 per cent over three years. That is the first fact of life, far more important than any attempt to go on SBS television. The fact of life is that this portfolio, which the RSL, other service groups in this country and both parties have consistently endorsed, is now going to be subject to very significant downsizing. The fact of a separate department providing this service has been a position that all parties have traditionally endorsed.

The secretary to the department, Dr Johnston, told the Senate estimates hearing on 12 June that, due to the combined effect of a number of changes instituted by the government, DVA staffing could be reduced by up to 30 per cent over the next three years. In the Hansard on page 329, he said:
We need to identify areas where we can contract out some of our business . . .
It is impossible to believe that cuts of this magnitude can be made without seriously reducing the level, quality, extent and timeliness of service to veterans.

We also know that the government has followed through with its predecessor's mortality study of Vietnam veterans. That showed suicide rates 21 per cent greater than in the comparative Australian population, an overall mortality rate seven per cent greater and a cancer rate of 21 per cent. There has been a follow‐up study.

This side of the House remains concerned that 1,805 veterans out there are not part of that study, have not been identified and are not part of the input. We join with the government in asking the veterans to make sure they do respond to this.
When he released the report, the minister promised:

BREAK.PARA: The federal government will implement a comprehensive program of health research, education and counselling to supplement existing benefits and services available to Vietnam veterans.

Now we discover, based on answers from the secretary to DVA, Dr Johnston, to questions from Labor senators at last week's Senate estimates hearings, that no additional budgetary resources have been allocated to follow up the findings. It was bad enough stuffing up the returns and causing a great degree of furore out there amongst these veterans by putting a gun at their head and telling them they had to get the returns back in a week or two. I am glad to see that he has rescinded that and actually given them a longer period to respond.

The secretary to the department said on the record that there will be no additional budgetary resources for the follow‐up to the findings. That was on 12 June. It is on page 349 of the Hansard. It is difficult to believe that the minister is truly intending to:
. . . supplement existing benefits and services—
when he has allocated not one additional dollar to do so, and the department itself is facing significant downsizing and looking at contracting out.

Similarly, the government has been loudly proclaiming its intention to provide a vocational rehabilitation scheme for younger ex‐service men and women. The idea behind it is quite worthy, quite commendable. However, at the same time, as part of the coalition's overall public service cutbacks implemented in recent legislation, they have cut the number of staff at the Vietnam Veterans' Counselling Service from 152 to 137. This is the very body that is central to the government's rehabilitation scheme. This means the service has to be taken as a new priority initiative with 15 fewer staff than they had in 1996‐97 to deal with a regular workload.

We have on previous occasions—and I am not the only person to raise this; the RSL has taken it up in recent weeks—had concerns about other aspects of this budget and its predecessor that are very much affecting veterans. It is all right for the minister to go around the country and say that he is not regarding the gold card as being in the too hard basket. The fact of life is: when Costello's got anything to say in this government—and I think he has a bit more to say than the minister—there is not going to be any change in the gold card. He knows it as well as I do. To start saying that he is in there fighting for them is really just totally irrelevant to the overall debate on what has happened in this last budget in regard to pharmaceuticals, what is happening in aged care and what is occurring around a broad frame of aged care as well.

What we do see, as I have indicated in other speeches, is savings of nearly $33 million over the next four years through the introduction from February 1998 of therapeutic goods premiums whereby veterans will have to pay the difference between higher price drugs within the group and the base price set. Another saving of $6 million over four years will come from the delisting in February 1998 of medicines for so‐called less serious medical conditions including antifungal and antidiarrhoea items.

The budget for this portfolio is going to be slashed by $40 million over the next years. It is all right to keep talking about how many canons he has patted on the back, and how many medals he has given out, and how many cheques he has handed over, et cetera. That is all very commendable but he does not have a position out there. People do not perceive that he is out there fighting on these more fundamental issues that affect the daily lives of aged veterans in this country.

It is also interesting to note that there will be savings of nearly $10 million over four years on the service pension outlays due to the introduction in July 1998 of a bonus plan to encourage eligible individuals to defer for up to five years applying for the pension. There are concerns that the veterans' affairs element of the plan is likely to focus on Vietnam veterans, who were shown in the recent Vietnam mortality study to have above average levels of mortality, particularly from cancer and suicide.

As I said, there is a variety of concerns. I have also had a number of approaches from Vietnam veterans' organisations—and others, to be honest—about the new panel diagnosis for certain conditions. Once again, the reality is that this is going to occur under the pretext that all of these veterans are supposedly cheating the government. These are people who have essentially given their service in very difficult circumstances, under fire, many of them. We have this allegation by this government, and I hear the departmental figures to groups that they have had discussions with that 5 per cent of them they regard as rorters. We are going to have this new attempt, particularly with regard to PTSD, basically to ensure that certain psychiatrist's medicals are not worth the paper that they are written on, to try to make it difficult for people to get through the process, difficult to win.

Another matter that veterans organisations have taken up with me is legal aid. I admit that some of these changes are not directly related to the minister's portfolio but we have a situation where veterans are concerned about things such as panel diagnosis and possible changes to tribunals. At the same time, this government, under the pretext of difficult arrangements and confusion between state and federal powers with regard to legal aid, and whether 5c too much was spent on a state matter, is dramatically slashing access to legal aid in this country. Some of the people that will be crucially hit will be veterans.

These are the more fundamental issues of concern to the veterans of this country. These are issues that are more important to their livelihood, to their families. These are issues that are more important to their widows than some of the aspects that the minister seems to believe are worthwhile diversions from the fundamental issues. We know that the widows of war veterans are going to be hit very hard in the area of aged care, and there is some speculation as to the charge that is going to be introduced. There have been estimates of an average of $80,000. Those estimates are not from the Labor Party shadow minister. They are not from the ACTU or any of the other so‐called bogey men out there; they are from the industry that will be gaining this money.

Obviously, those people who are paying that kind of figure are being forced to sell their house under pressure from this government. That is because Mr Costello's National Commission of Audit report says that there are too many asset‐rich people out there avoiding responsibility for aged care. The veteran community in this country thinks that the minister's hard end should be going to such matters as the death tax. That is what he should be combating. He should be fighting for those sorts of matters and not worrying about the peripheral bread and circus diversions.

A subject of recent months has been this toing‐and‐froing over the recognition of overseas medals. This fits in with the question of the credibility of the government. We had the former shadow minister, Mr Tuckey, running around every possible RSL conference that he could get a leg in, for a year or two beforehand, saying that he did not care if people got imperial honours, that he was going to be in there as soon as he got his seat on the cabinet benches getting them another award because they deserve `a distinctly Australian award'. It is quite obvious that he knew that they were already receiving an imperial award and he was saying they should get a second one.

I am very pleased to see the level of discontent and the level of criticism in the newspaper columns in this country, both from individuals who have had their heads kicked in over this issue and from a variety of service groups, with the last‐minute excuse by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel (Mrs Bishop). They have suddenly found this new capital offence called double medalling. This is a very serious matter, this double medalling, despite the fact that the predecessor had made it emphatically clear that he was aware of it and he was saying there should be a second medal. The minister herself of course went around the RSL national conference saying that she was still there with Wilson Tuckey and she had the same policy.

On 23 September 1996, the minister issued a press release at the national conference saying, `I am pleased to announce that the government's policy is largely in place, with the Governor‐General having already approved changes to the determinations for the medals under his authority and Her Majesty's consent is being sought for other changes.'

Subsequently, the minister was forced to admit in question time on 28 May 1997 that the coalition would not honour this commitment to those who served in the Korean war, the Malayan emergency and the Indonesian confrontation. Eight months after she had said everything was on track, that all the necessary approvals were in train and after thousands of applications had been received, the minister pleaded that, `It was indeed then discovered that those people had been awarded an imperial medal at the behest of the Australian government and therefore it was an Australian medal rendered in respect of that active service in Korea, in the Malayan emergency and in the Indonesian confrontation. Accordingly, the government made a decision that that would represent double medalling and that that would not be done.'

A fortnight later it looks like there is going to be another backflip because a significant number of opposition backbenchers are a bit embarrassed around the place. They are getting a bit of heat. They are getting a few phone calls and of course in the Melbourne Herald‐Sun of 11 June we see a little leak there that the government would announce a medals about‐turn in two weeks time. Once again, there is a question of the degree of honesty in this government and the degree of belief in what they are saying.

I want to return to the point on which I originally had trouble with the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. That is the question of employment in this country. I note at the outset that I have to quote these figures from June 1996 because the government is incapable, in response to a question on notice from myself, of giving me any updated figures. I want to say to this minister that whilst it is commendable that we actually do honour the dead and we do recognise those who died overseas for this country, I still say very clearly that unemployment in this country and particularly in western Sydney is fairly important. Quite frankly, it is a major indictment of this government that the only job creation scheme they did come up with in the last budget was in fact this thing for war graves overseas. I wish they had many other schemes.

The figures of June 1996 show that in Auburn municipality there is unemployment of 19.4 per cent, Holroyd 9.9 per cent and Parramatta 10.5 per cent. There are a few qualifications in the minister's answer on that question. He says, `They are not exact and accordingly should be read with caution.' They are `subject to greater variability', et cetera. All of the quibbling, all of the prevarication and all of the qualifications in the world do not take away from this government's slashing of labour market programs by $1.8 billion in the previous budget. It does not get away from the fact that this government, unlike its predecessor, does not have a target like Labor did of five per cent unemployment. For all of the attempt by the Prime Minister to talk about average figures over the years of Labor government, it can not escape the fact that in the first 15 months of the Labor government, unemployment in this country went down from 10 per cent to 8.9 per cent. In contrast in the same period of time the Howard government has managed to drive it upwards to 8.8 per cent.

As the Prime Minister said, and I very rarely agree with his comments, on television last week, `The government in power is seen as responsible for this'.More than ever, if there is a government around the place that is responsible for unemployment, it is this one.

What we have seen is a slashing of labour market programs by $1.8 billion. That is in contrast to its predecessor's very graphic lifting of expenditure on active labour market programs. It had not been a trend previously in this country to be preoccupied with active programs, but Labor did that. They lifted it from 0.27 per cent of GDP to 0.73 per cent by 1994‐95. But what we have seen from this government is a tax on export market development grants; a tax on research and development assistance; a tax on DIFF; a tax on bounties; and a tax on every possible assistance to industry in regard to unemployment.

This government has slashed labour market programs. They have slashed a variety of positions for young people, and they are now coming out with the concept of amalgamating the CES and other government instrumentalities into so‐called one‐stop shop agencies. Last week, we had the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) on TV saying that small business, and even the prospective employees, can pay $250. I want to quote a constituent of mine, Miss Alarna Tufrey of Merrylands. She wrote:
Due to government changes that I was not aware of, I found that I was ineligible for a youth allowance, so I went back to school to attempt year 11 but found I it very difficult and left.
She goes on to say:
My mother has taken time off work to help me. We went to Granville TAFE and asked for some information on different courses to be mailed to me for the next semester.
It was then that we were informed that the Merrylands CES office—
and, I might add, not only the CES but the Medicare office as well—
will be closing, and that I should take advantage of any help they can offer me until then.
More importantly, she says—and I well understand that, in the last election, the perception of youth unemployment in this country critically hurt Labor:

As a teenager I have no confidence in the Liberal Federal Government, and I have no intention of voting for them. I have friends who also use the CES services to look for jobs and training, and I can assure you that they feel the same way. We need the CES to help us, their advice is invaluable and the security of knowing that they are there to help anyone who is unemployed goes a long way to the peace of mind of the younger people.
This is my first letter to a Member of Parliament, and I can only hope that this shows you the importance of the services that the Government is taking away from us. When I finally gain employment—
and let us hope she does—
I will have to pay taxes and vote. I can only hope that I can make a small difference now.

That is the reality out there: after 15 months, the public can average out what happened under Labor. The fact of life is that Labor's figures were in a time of contemporaneous international recession.

The situation now is that this country is obviously very much affected by its trading partners. The fact of life in the United States and in most of the Western world has been a far better employment situation than that which was concurrent with the Labor regime and, despite that, we have got a situation where unemployment is growing continually, and we have hit a record in 23 months with regard to long‐term unemployment.
That is the kind of agenda that the government has had in this budget. That is the kind of policy that they have employed. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Barresi, Phil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the coalition government's second budget, in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1997‐98. Before I commence, I will make a couple of passing comments in answer to those that have just been made by the member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson). I note that most of his address was directed towards the issue of veterans' affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: I would say, in defence of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Scott), what a splendid job he has done in the past 16 to 17 months. Without the fanfare of Australia Remembers marking 50 years, he has diligently applied himself to the task at hand. `Their Service—Our Heritage' has gone down as an excellent program in the electorate. I do note, though, the member for Reid's comments about the gold card, and the anticipation that is out there amongst some of the veterans. If we can deal with some of the remaining issues that have been cropping up in more recent times with regard to the Vietnam veterans, I am certainly totally supportive of that.

My principal comment in regard to the member for Reid is in terms of his claim about Labor's record on unemployment. The fact which has been neglected in all of this is that the average rate of unemployment that Labor had from 1990 to 1996 was—and despite all of the claims that they make—somewhere around 8.6 per cent: that was their average, their unemployment record. They can stand here and talk about the Howard government's record—or lack of record, to use their words—in terms of unemployment. But, after 15 months of economic reform, as compared with their 13 years, we certainly can hold our heads up high.

We have managed to bring down this budget without increasing taxes. This should never be forgotten by those on the other side, and I know that the Australian public in turn also acknowledges this point. There are no increases in petrol tax, there are no increases in personal tax and there is no increase in the Medicare tax. This is a budget which has consolidated the efforts of the budget that was brought down last year in August. It delivers ongoing policy consistency and it delivers certainty for all Australians.

More particularly, the budget confirms our solid commitment to the needs and aspirations of ordinary Australians: those working men and women, their families, the aged pensioners and the self‐funded retirees—the very people who make up my electorate of Deakin. Through this budget the Howard government has reaffirmed its credentials as a responsible economic manager. It is a government that is willing to tackle the longer term structural reforms so desperately needed. In stark contrast to our approach, we have Labor's policy of inconsistencies and reversals. By jettisoning past policies, the opposition have shown themselves for what they really are—political opportunists.

BREAK.PARA: In an international comparative sense, many Australians may not realise the abundant opportunities that are available here in this country. In contrast to those looking to the politics of blame and for scapegoats—and we have seen a few of those in this House—I would like to highlight the fact that Australia continues to be a great place to live and work.

Recently I had the good fortune to travel to Taiwan. The message I brought home from this trip was that the quality of Australian products and services should never be underestimated and should never be talked down, particularly by members of this federal parliament. They are as good as those anywhere else in the world.

The coalition's approach to government is to prepare the way for a strong, vibrant, cohesive society—a society that can more than match it with the tiger economies to our north. This massive task is ongoing, and I am glad to say that the report card to this point in time is quite favourable.
The Herald‐Sun newspaper in my city of Melbourne said on 14 May:

Peter Costello has decisively buried the Keating legacy—in more ways than one. It very clearly establishes his fiscal and economic and political . . . credentials. It consolidates our nation's finances around a small government dynamic.

Of course, it is not only Peter Costello who has decisively buried the Keating legacy, but the Australian Labor Party has also decisively buried the Keating legacy and, as I say, jettisoned its previous policies.

The days of debt and deficit spending are over. Labor's approach gave us, as a nation, an increase in government debt of billions of dollars. The reality of a less than responsible budgetary approach is that financial problems only get worse. As every mortgagee knows, paying interest on interest already accrued will over time become very costly. The longer the debt is not responsibly managed, the larger it grows. A downward spiral of deficit and debt leads to a feeling of frustration, hopelessness and finally desperation as one loses control.

The public knows our nation was heading down this path. They demanded responsible economic management, and the Commonwealth has responded by ensuring that the budget is balanced across the economic cycle. Two excellent and very responsible budgets have been brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and by the Howard government. Unfortunately, this simple principle was lost on Labor. Despite economic growth, their budget was in deficit—year after year their budgets were in deficit.

Through this budget, the coalition has placed Australia on the path to increased savings. Governments and companies, as well as individuals, need to be encouraged to put aside more financial resources. Through increased savings, our reliance on foreign borrowings can be drastically reduced.

The bottom line with increased savings is faster economic growth and, importantly, jobs. These two budgets have been all about jobs. There has been a multi‐dimensional attack on the issue of jobs, not the one dimensional attack that Labor employed of simply pouring money into labour market programs. Nobody knows better the waste of the labour market programs than me. I was one of the subcontractors who had to stand at the front of a room and deliver a message of hope and possible success once the two weeks, six weeks or eight weeks was over. It was hard to take. It was hard to have to look into the faces of the young kids, the retirees and those who were retrenched later in life knowing that, when they walked out of the room, Labor was not offering another job; Labor was simply offering another training program. This budget is a multi‐dimensional attack, and we will succeed. As I said before, I am pleased to say that, after 15 months, the budget report card is quite favourable and getting better by the month.

For its part, the coalition has set a good savings example. This budget predicts that the Commonwealth budget will be in surplus over three years. We have gone from a $10.5 billion deficit to a $1.6 billion surplus. Most importantly, this position has been achieved in a just and fair manner. All sectors of society have contributed, which is in contrast to the ideology driven, high spending `tax the rich' New South Wales Labor budget. The New South Wales budget is a reminder at state and federal level that Labor's old taxing and spending habits do die hard. This budget makes it easier for individuals to save.

All taxpayers in the Deakin electorate will be eligible for a 15 per cent tax rebate. Once the scheme is fully implemented, the rebate will apply to the first $3,000 of taxable income from savings, whatever the source, be it bank interest, superannuation contributions or dividend income. The maximum rebate of $450 will accrue on $3,000 worth of savings. Put another way, that is a $450 tax cut. Around six million people will benefit from this incentive scheme, and most benefit will go to those with taxable incomes under $40,000. In my electorate this represents approximately 45 per cent of households. They will receive the maximum benefit of $450. For those paying a 20c marginal rate, the rebate scheme offers a 15 per cent tax cut for every dollar of savings.

Why is it that the most positive and beneficial policies attract the most strident criticism—criticism that is misinformed and misleading? Scare campaigns and misinformation, now characteristic of this opposition, are not appreciated by the average citizen. My constituents tell me they do not appreciate the ALP playing political games with their lives and the futures of their families.

I pose the question: would all Australians potentially benefit from Labor's l‐a‐w tax promises as they benefit from this government's savings plan? The answer, of course, is no. But it gets worse for the opposition. On national TV the member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans) said:
I'm talking about the abandonment of the superannuation co‐contribution, in favour of a little windfall tax break for those who don't need or deserve it.

I will throw those words back at the member for Holt at an appropriate time. He has added another beauty to the ALP's quotable quotes list, and demonstrates once again Labor's `we know what is best for you' uncaring attitude. It is obvious from that comment that Labor thinks the self‐funded retirees of Deakin do not need or deserve a tax rebate on their hardearned savings. I take issue with that comment and the opposition's suggestion, and I am sure that the good citizens of Deakin think the same way.

There certainly are quite a lot of other areas I could tackle but, in line with our time commitments made for this debate, I would say in conclusion that the coalition government is committed to doing the right thing by all Australians. This budget continues the strategy of repairing the mess left by Labor. It will also bring certainty, economic security and, above all, a climate for increased employment. I congratulate the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) for their responsible solutions to Labor's 13 years of neglect.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was interesting to listen to the contribution from the member for Deakin (Mr Barresi) who I think said in part of his contribution that employment was going up under this government. Fascinating! Members of the cabinet seem to be not only illiterate but also innumerate.

BREAK.PARA: Recently, I have been reading a book called The Unconscious Civilisation by John Ralston Saul. While I do not agree with everything that Saul says in the book, I was particularly taken by some of his remarks, one of which I would like to quote here. Saul says at the beginning of his book:

There is a general sense that our civilisation is in a long‐term crisis. It can been seen from the political, social or economic aspect. From each angle, the same crisis can be seen differently. I would like to argue that it took on its actual economic form in 1973, when a first wave of political crises lead to an oil supply crisis. We have been in a depression ever since. It does not resemble a 1929‐style depression, but then depressions have always been different, one from the other. Ours has been softened and evened out thanks to the life preservers gradually put in place by society after 1929 in order to give us more time to manoeuvre and act should a disaster repeat itself. It did, in 1973. Now, given our inability over the past two decades to deal with an unbreakable chain of unemployment, debt, inflation and no real growth, we have drifted farther and farther out into a cold, unfriendly, confusing sea. The new certitude of those in positions of authority—those out of the water—is that the certain answer is to cut away the life preservers. This might be called a childlike act. Or one of unconsciousness so profound as to constitute stupidity.

Of course, I believe that the changes in this budget fit Saul's description and, without doubt, constitute stupidity. In particular, the government's failure to put in place mechanisms to stimulate the economy and thereby create employment is a prime example of the government cutting away the life‐preservers.

Last Thursday, the Australian Bureau of Statistics released new labour force data. To the shame of the Howard government, that data revealed that unemployment continues to grow. Indeed, in one month 40,000 jobs disappeared—40,000 jobs disappeared, and my colleague opposite says that this government has made progress! The continued climb in unemployment has resulted in more than 809,000 Australians being out of work today: nearly 1 million Australians out of work.

Unemployment is the most insidious wound John Howard has inflicted on the people of Australia, because it affects every aspect of a person's life. It has implications for their standard of living, for their health, for their ability to plan and save for their future—and that, of course, is now an imperative, given the government's new policies on aged care—and for their ability to educate their children. The list goes on and on.

I would like briefly to address a couple of the points that I have alluded to but first I would like to draw to the attention of the Committee the government's disastrous record on unemployment. In western societies, your job provides much more than your living. It provides you with social status, a sense of where you are in society. It is your identifier: `I'm an electrician,' or `I work for an insurance company.' The first inquiry we usually make of someone, once we know their name, is what do they do for a living. When we ask children what they want to do when they grow up, we expect them to name a trade or a profession.

Labor has always recognised the importance to Australians of having a job. Our policies assured Australians that the safety net—or, in Saul's terms, the life‐preserver—was always firmly in place. When restructuring threatened whole areas of this country's economy, Labor set about instituting policies and programs to re‐educate the work force and reposition people into areas of job growth. Labor planned. It had a vision of where Australia was going, and we did all that we could to reduce the unemployment that was caused by us getting there.

This budget was the government's opportunity to put in place its plan and to institute its own job creation policies. Unfortunately for Australia, the Liberal Party has no such plan. John Howard has no such vision. He does not care about the effect unemployment has on people— because, if he did, he would be doing something about it. Rather he is taking on those policies discredited following Margaret Thatcher's term in government in Great Britain: sink or swim policies, with no lifeboats or life preservers in sight.

I think it is sad, in a sense, that the Prime Minister, on his current journey to Britain, will be going to have those unfortunate Thatcherite policies reinforced in his mind when he sees Baroness Thatcher. One can only hope that he will be more impressed, and have more of an effect made on him, by the policies of the new Labour government in Britain.

In last year's budget, the government cut public sector jobs, abolished employment programs, cut skills training and slashed industry programs. Now that that has resulted in increased unemployment, the Prime Minister is giving Australians more of the same. The economy has become stagnant. Confidence is at an all‐time low and business has stopped investing. Retail sales are down. Indeed, nearly every indicator is down. Without growth in the economy there can be no growth in employment. It is not just the Labor Party saying this; business is saying it, small business is saying it, the retail sector is saying it. Everybody is saying that this government is running the country into a recession.

When BHP's closure of the steel mill in Newcastle saw 2,000 Australians dumped out of their jobs, what did the government do? The Prime Minister did nothing, the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) went to a casino opening, and the Prime Minister still has not found time to visit Newcastle since it happened. He has time to go to Lord's and he has time to go to stay at the Savoy Hotel in London. He can find time for the cricket in England, but he cannot find time to visit Newcastle. Two thousand Australians have lost their jobs, and the Prime Minister does not care. The government can give us no plans or policies about what they will do for Newcastle, just platitudes. If there is a metaphor for John Howard's government, it is in the very tardy approach that they have taken to what has happened to the people in Newcastle.

In fact, the only response the Liberals can make when they are questioned about unemployment is to say they are changing Australia's industrial laws; that is supposed to be how it works. Well it has not been enough and it will not be enough. The Liberal's new industrial relations environment will deliver lower wages and longer working hours for those Australians who are lucky enough to still be in a job. Forty thousand jobs lost last month; 800,000 Australians out of work; and all the government can say is, `Somehow or other, if you'll allow people to find a way to sack people quicker and more efficiently, that will create work.' I have always found that rather circular argument a bit strange. None of the changes that the government has made in the industrial relations area will result in a rise in employment. They have not so far, and they will not in the future.

Australians at all levels of society are becoming disillusioned with this government's attitude to jobs and are now starting to drop out of the work force. In Thursday's job figures we saw a huge fall in the participation rate, but my colleague over on the other side says that it is all going well. Indeed, the participation rate—

TALK.START.PARA: —The policies are there, mate; just wait.

—The participation rate for males is at its lowest on record and he says, `Just wait.' That is a terrific answer for the people in my electorate who do not have a job—just wait. The problem is going to be that if you are a male who is in your 50s and you lose your job under this government, you will have a long, long wait until you find another job. You will have a long, long wait, you will not have anything coming in and life will cost you more.

BREAK.PARA: Most Australians are too busy swimming to be able to wait; without life preservers they cannot afford to stop long enough to be relaxed and comfortable the way the Prime Minister would like us to be. It might be very relaxing and very comfortable flying first class to Britain to see the cricket. The view from Lord's or Kirribilli might be pretty cosy, pretty rosy, pretty relaxed and pretty comfortable. But the view from Kingsgrove in my electorate most certainly is not.

What happens to those people who lose their jobs? Along with the loss of their pride, identity and confidence, often comes a worsening in their health. One of the greatest contributors to your health, or otherwise, is your employment status. Unemployed people are much more likely to suffer from illness and, once ill, to take much longer to recover.

How does this government help social security recipients and low income people when their health is compromised? They make them wait. In this budget the government has selected the less fortunate and targeted them with a new drugs tax. Under the government's new scheme, those Australians seeking access to the safest and most effective drugs will have to pay more, up to $30 a month more. Low income earners wanting to use these drugs will be forced to pay more or accept second‐rate drugs. The drugs affected by the government's new drug tax make up around one third of pharmaceutical benefits scheme spending as they treat chronic conditions such as high blood pressure, high cholesterol, ulcers and depression, in patients who have often been on these drugs for years.

In another move which will unfairly affect low income earners, the government is also closing 44 Medicare offices in urban areas. Those on tight budgets will now have to travel further to claim their rebates.

Another of the life preservers put in place by Labor governments over the decades, and even by Liberal governments, to protect the vulnerable has been aged care, and the people on the other side say `Rubbish'. They obviously think that is rubbish because they do not want to see anything done to protect aged Australians, the generation of people who went through the Depression, the Second World War, and who are now in their 70s and 80s and wanting to go into a nursing home. This government's answer to them is, `Come up with $80,000'. That is what they are going to have to do. The government commenced that process in the last budget and continues down that road now.

The government has introduced a scheme of accommodation bonds for elderly people which will be the cruellest thing any government has done to old people in Australia since the Second World War. Those who are in a position of authority, those who are out of the water, who have had no experience of being at the mercy of others because of their financial status or poor health, are the ones who have forced these older Australians to have to sell their houses, or else have their children put up the money.

These elderly people are people who have struggled all their lives to purchase a home yet now they will be placed in the invidious position of having to sell that house in order to purchase a place in a nursing home. Those who have not been fortunate enough to earn enough money to buy their own home will be in an even worse position. They will be at the mercy of nursing home owners and operators who will be able to pick and choose between applicants who have the money and those who have not.

Even nursing home owners and operators have objected to the government's policies in this area. One example in my electorate is St Basil's Home. They have written to me setting out a large number of concerns that they have with the government's program. Amongst the issues noted by Father Kapetas, the director of that service, as being of concern are appropriate prudential arrangements for the accommodation bonds, inadequate funding levels, a lack of indexation of those funding levels to meet the care needs of residents, and the lack of an external complaints handling process for residents.

During the debate on these bills, the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) did nothing to allay these concerns and many others raised by members. The government sees nothing wrong with making people pay their way, even if those people cannot afford it. There goes another life preserver.

The Prime Minister's lack of vision was never more evident than in relation to education. In 1996 the government took huge chunks out of the education budget, using the argument that those benefiting from education should pay. What he fails to appreciate is that Australia needs a better educated work force now than ever before. Countries seeking to grow their economies can only do so with a work force which is well educated and able to be retrained throughout their working lives. By preventing or punishing those seeking to gain an education, this government is doing the country a huge disservice.

And this year's budget is no better than last year's. An amount of $72 million has been cut from vocational education and training grants to the states, and that is on top of the $183 million cut last year. The situation in relation to Austudy remains confused and is still a stumbling block to the children of low income earners seeking a tertiary education. Some 4,700 places are being cut through the abolition of the Commonwealth industry places scheme, and a further one per cent cut to funding to universities, coming as it does on top of last year's five per cent cut, will mean even fewer student places. Universities are slowly but surely being forced to give places over to fee paying students, those there on the basis of ability to pay rather than merit.

Of particular relevance to my electorate and the students who live there was the announcement by the University of New South Wales that it is closing its St George campus. This means that those wishing to study must travel much further to access relevant courses. The St George campus closure is a direct result of the cuts to university funding by the Howard government. Australia is going backwards to the period when all students paid fees and only the children of the rich or those lucky enough to win a scholarship could gain access to the highest level of education. Society's life‐preservers of a better educated citizenry seem to be in the process of being jettisoned.

I could go on and on listing those areas where this government has attacked the very basis of our society—the safety net which was so carefully put in place over the decades by the Menzies government, the Whitlam government, the Fraser government and the Hawke and Keating governments. The unravelling of that safety net is happening at a very fast pace. Every time the people from my electorate look around, another life‐preserver has been cast adrift.

Without the security provided by those life‐preservers, society is starting to turn in on itself. People are looking for scapegoats, and this government, by its inaction, has created the monster of the One Nation Party. Unfortunately, I do not think the government is capable of nor willing to do anything to ensure that the problems it has created can be corrected. The government has allowed the Pauline Hanson cancer to spread across Australia—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I think it would be appropriate if the honourable member referred to members by their electorate. The appropriate title is the member for Oxley.

—I thought we were talking in a generic sense in that this is a cancer of the One Nation Party, which was formed by the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). The One Nation Party cancer that she has spread across the country is something which will do Australia harm both at home and overseas. The government has been unwilling or unable to do anything about that. That is a shame for Australia. It is a shame for this parliament, and it is a shame that there are so few members on the government side who will stand up to this cancer.

BREAK.PARA: When we look at where Australia will be going at the turn of the century, where our country will be at the centenary of Federation and what sort of a country we want to hand over to our children, it should not be a mean‐spirited and mean‐natured country. It should be a country that, rather than jettisoning the lifeboats and cutting away the life‐preservers, offers a helping hand to those who come here, to those who live here who are not as well off as some, and to those who want to make Australia the best country in the world to live in. I believe it is only by adopting that approach that we can progress as a nation.

When one sees the Prime Minister using the metaphor of Sir Robert Menzies and the tradition of the Liberal Party, one wonders whether Menzies and the people of his generation are turning in their graves. While there were very significant ideological differences between them and the Labor Party, I am sure that we agreed with many of the social things that the Menzies government did.

I was a member of this parliament in the years that Malcolm Fraser was the Prime Minister of Australia. I always gave great credit to former Senator Margaret Guilfoyle, a very senior minister in that government, who always used to ensure that, while Fraser talked about axing and not taxing, the safety nets in this country were kept at such a level that those who were not as well off as others could survive and prosper.

Unfortunately, the budget last year and the budget this year have seen a very radical change from the approach that Liberal governments tended to take. The quote we saw in the paper last week from the Prime Minister when he arrived at cabinet many years ago, saying, `I'm not a Liberal; I'm a large `C' Conservative,' was shown to be very true in the structure of this year's budget brought down by the government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hardgrave, Gary, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be associated with the second Howard government budget. Through the passing of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 199798, we will see some more way‐ahead programs in place and opportunity for more Australians, as detailed in this budget. That go forward is certainly detailed in the bill before us.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a bill which offers an integrated approach. It is not a series of disparate ideas; it is a coordinated approach with the future in mind. It is all about Australians investing in themselves, their country, their companies and their jobs. It is about the creation of real jobs—jobs which can be sustained because industries will grow and confidence will return.

It is all about people in small business in my electorate of Moreton who are concerned about a lot of the things that most average Australians are concerned about. There is a dent in the Australian psyche after 13 years of Labor government, which the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) is trying to revisit and trying to revise in his contribution here tonight. There are people in my electorate who remain hurt and scared, whose confidence is dented. They have been hurt by the false starts and the promises of that Labor regime. What do Labor say these days: if only they had a fourteenth year, it would have been okay.

I certainly do support the approach that the Treasurer (Mr Costello) has offered. We do not need any more boom and bust in this country; we need no more kick in the guts economics as one lever is pulled here and something else is pulled there to just go on and produce more hurt and confusion. This government instead is working on the big structural changes, sustained and substantial economic growth and a return of a sense of security for Australians. We are talking about low inflation. We are talking about steady growth over the next decade. We are talking about repairing the financial situation that Labor left us. We are talking about reducing debt. We are talking about boosting investment. All of this equals job creation, and that is what it is all about.

If throwing money at job creation would have solved the problems of unemployment, Labor would have fixed them. Instead, over 13 years they averaged 8.7 per cent unemployment in this country. Yet they stand here in their contributions to this debate and try and revisit the whole thing and suggest they have all the answers now. If only they had a fourteenth or fifteenth year, they keep saying. Let us face it, Mr Deputy Speaker, all Labor do is knock. All they want to do is knock, and prevent the government from getting on with its established program.

If you look at the recent Yellow Pages business survey, it showed that 30 per cent of small business believes the economy a year from now will be better, and 13 per cent say it will be worse. For my money, I will go with the 30 per cent.

In the survey, small business was also asked what its prime concerns were. Third on the list of prime concerns was cash flow, at 11 per cent. The second concern for small business was lack of sales at 21 per cent. According to that Yellow Pages small business survey, the number one prime concern of the small business sector, a concern for 28 per cent of small business people, was none; there was absolutely no concern for them. The number one concern of 28 per cent of small business operators was no concern at all.

The Labor opposition in recent weeks has been touting the positive‐negative indicators of that particular survey. Statistically, this outlines where the positives outweigh the negatives in the survey. This latest Yellow Pages index shows that negatives outweigh the positives to the tune of minus six per cent. That is a vast improvement on the last such survey under the previous government, where the result was minus 51 per cent. In other words, while small business would like to be happier—and I am sure most people on the government side understand all of this—the one thing that is for certain is that they are far more confident than when Labor was in power.

We will keep working on that growing confidence. We will keep working on the job of restoring confidence to the small business sector and, as the policies and measures we have undertaken kick in, confidence will grow even stronger.

Already we have seen evidence of the growth in confidence. The March quarter capital expenditure survey backs up the basis of the bill which is before us this evening: strong growth in business investment in 1996‐97. Business is starting to gear up again. Total capital expenditure in the first three quarters of 1996‐97 is 21 per cent higher than it was for the equivalent period a year ago. Business investment is very strong—at record levels—because of this government's lead. Interest rates are in fact at historic lows, and in addition the budget is turning from deficit to surplus.

What is the Labor opposition's approach on all of this? They have basically opposed every point. The government's efforts to lock in monetary targets, low inflation, agreements between the Reserve Bank and the government: Labor just raved on and threatened to sue. The government's policy to take a $10.3 billion deficit and produce a $1.6 billion budget surplus was voted against on all measures by Labor.

While this government stands for savings, low deficits, reduced debt and low interest rates, Labor is still the party of high deficits—who cares about that, they say—high debt, high interest rates, high taxes and no small business accommodation.

No‐one on the opposition side understands small business. There was evidence enough of that after 13 years of its dreadful government. While on this side we stand for small business, the return of confidence, investment and the creation of real jobs, in the Labor Party the contrast continues. Labor wants to slow down our programs of reform and thwart our efforts through the Senate. The Australian Democrats and the ALP should stand condemned for the hurt that their delays are causing.

The great debate is starting—and we would like it to be a mature debate—on the question of reform of the taxation system. Everybody in this country, except the Labor Party, accepts that there is a need for reform. Already, it is showing it wants to play politics yet again. If Labor delays the reforms that may come out of the debate process, battlers in this country, people on average wages, are going to start paying the top rate of tax. Rather than grow up and participate in a mature debate on the taxation system, Labor would much rather see average weekly wage earners paying the top rate of tax. It would much rather see more job losses in the public sector, as well as the private, rather than face up to tax reform.

After all, the evidence is there—elements of last year's budget were still being passed the day before this year's budget was introduced. A good example of the effect of that is the Mount Gravatt Training Centre in my electorate. Pat Milley and her team have been waiting for the new training regime to start. They have been putting time and effort in since this government came to power, planning for the future.

That centre is committed to the training of people for new jobs, and yet the Labor‐Democrat cabal and its delays in the Senate have caused lost staff, lost expertise, a decline in the esprit de corps, and lost morale. They will not pass those bills in the Senate. They have put them in a very long queue. What about the thousands of people in and around my electorate who could have been helped by the training that Pat and her team wanted to provide? Does Labor care? Obviously not, otherwise it would expedite matters in the other place.

Compare this reckless approach to the devil‐may‐care, all risk, no responsibility approach of Crean and the $2 billion new work opportunities approach of the previous government. That $2 billion new work opportunities fiasco is part of the debt reduction program costs that we now face as a government. So desperate was the previous government to cover up unemployment before the last election, it threw money at it—$2 billion.

One group which received funds in my electorate was the Brisbane South Community Group. Between 21 August and 7 November 1995, that group received $618,952 in three separate contracted amounts. It has received nothing since this government came to office. That was frustrating for me at the outset because I sought to represent their views and concerns, but now I understand why they have not received the money. It is because the earlier funds have not been acquitted. In other words, over $600,000 was thrown at this community group under Labor—under its drunken spending spree on new work opportunities—and no money has so far been acquitted.

Former employees of this particular organisation have raised matters with me, as have so many others in my local community who have lent moral support to Brisbane South Community Group—churches, service clubs, political representatives on all sides—and I now feel rather used and cheated by this organisation. Brisbane South Community Group failed to pay employees. It failed to pay the Australian Taxation Office PAYE collections. It failed to pay rent. It failed to pay Telstra bills. It failed to do a lot of things, and yet it was the recipient of money under the devil‐may‐care approach of the previous government.

The Brisbane South Community Group has been kicked out of its Annerley office in my electorate. It has been kicked out of the Victoria Point office in the electorate of the honourable member for Fadden and Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Jull). It claims that the Mount Gravatt office is still operating—it is an office which we shared with the member for Griffith (Mr McDougall). This organisation has taken taxpayer funds and not accounted for them. Past staff, community group members, service club members and local schools have all painted the same picture to me.

Rosebud Hansen, a tireless worker in the Annerley area, and Kaye Bailey were two ex‐workers who took action, quite rightly, before the Industrial Relations Commission recently.
