They are seeking redress for their wage complaints. Last month the company chairman, Robin Whittaker, was ordered to pay $10,000 to those two women. If funds are not paid by the end of June, a warrant will be issued allowing police to seize property belonging to the company and to Mr Whittaker. The ATO is also after the Brisbane South Community Group for failure to pay $64,073 in group income tax.

The company started to fail to pay wages in February 1996, just three months after the last dollop of Labor's NWO slush fund was received. The Queensland government has even chipped in with over $40,000 in funds last year for programs run by Rosebud Hansen, and yet she was not paid. I have been lobbied since the election by the group, especially by program coordinator, Aaron Lucas. I went in to bat for them because they presented themselves so well, had the backing of so many good, decent, committed citizens in my electorate, and had high aspirations. However, along with so many others, I know I have been used and misled. Where the funds have gone and why the hopes of hundreds of young unemployed have been dashed are questions which beg an answer.

It is obvious to me that the Brisbane South Community Group was born out of an unreal environment prior to the last election. It was encouraged by a government which really was not interested in job creation, it was interested only in hiding the unemployed. So over $600,000 worth of taxpayers' funds have not been acquitted. Yet, down to their last breath, they are claiming the lack of acquittal of funds arises because of some obscure litigation involving their auditor.

This Mr Aaron Lucas has also used my representations to Senator Vanstone seeking clarification of a lack of funds from the new government as an excuse to debtors. It also seems that he claimed constantly that more money was coming and that bills would be paid. Essentially, the imprimatur of the government's new programs was being used by this group. This government has not fallen for that, unlike the previous government.

It has been frustrating to me that while my representations on behalf of so many other groups have been successful, this group was unsuccessful, but now we know. I must say that if only DEETYA had been more forthcoming earlier, that if only Labor had been more responsible with the funds that it threw at new work opportunities prior to the last elections, this money would never have been wasted.

BREAK.PARA: Essentially, the whole episode disgusts me and so many others in my community. Local papers will be running this story tomorrow. I must say that when it is all said and done, in the context of this bill before us today, it is refreshing to see that we now have a government that has focused on real job creation, on long‐term investment that is going to produce results, and is not prepared to just throw money at the problem and hope it fixes itself, as Labor did.

There is no doubt that the Labor Party and the Democrats will stand in the way of so many more of this new government's efforts to do something genuine for the unemployed, and that amazes me. If this bill is not passed wholly in the Senate, then those two parties should stand condemned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gash, Joanna, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to participate in this debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1997‐98. For my electorate of Gilmore, this budget has been a good news budget as it acknowledges my three core commitments to the electorate: investment, infrastructure and jobs. The Treasurer's statements were well received as the people of Gilmore are fully aware of the pressing economic circumstances that make the need to balance the budget a government priority. It is something they understand in their own lives. They know that no‐one can live beyond their means and that if you owe money, it has to be paid back. They understand that ultimately they will be the people who have to repay that debt.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, it is certainly good news to see the government widen its ongoing commitment to Gilmore by providing solutions to the very real problems facing rural and regional Australia. However, a good budget alone, no matter how positive the initiatives, no matter how high the level of government financial commitment, is still not sufficient to address the real social problems faced by too many families in Gilmore. Although today I will speak about what Gilmore has gained, not for a moment have I lost sight of what is still to be achieved in an area in which unemployment and concerns for small business remain very high.

After 13 years in which the difficulties faced by Gilmore were not recognised, I have always maintained that, given some assistance in providing infrastructure, then investments, jobs and self-reliance would follow. Whilst this budget makes no direct reference to our much needed major highway link, Main Road 92, the Shoalhaven Highway, work is continuing with the three tiers of government working together in preparing a feasibility study for making this major highway link a reality. There is no doubt that this access to the Hume Highway and Canberra is of vital importance to Gilmore's economic future.

Our export markets are increasing and we need an alternate route through which to transport our goods. At the moment the beautiful, environmentally sensitive area of Kangaroo Valley is bearing the brunt of the traffic, and the trucks, and now double-B bogies, as there is simply no alternative to the Nowra‐Canberra‐Melbourne freight connection.

Already there has been a commitment made by the Shoalhaven City Council in funding the initial studies that have proven the immense cost-benefit ratio to my electorate and adjoining regions and I congratulate the Shoalhaven City Council on showing the required leadership in dealing with such a pressing issue.

There is no doubt that, with the commenced upgrading of HMAS Albatross, Main Road 92 will allow further gains to be made by easier, quicker access to defence links and embassies in Canberra. This will then become a road link of national significance.

The commencement of the eastern gas pipeline also displays confidence in my electorate of Gilmore with the major part of its construction following the proposed Main Road 92 route. This would clearly provide for the expansion of those areas, thus guaranteeing future investment in the area and much needed job creation.

Whilst the Department of Defence has been, to a great extent, immune to the hardship experienced by other departments, a great deal of internal restructuring has taken place. Fortunately for the people of Gilmore, this has meant increased spending on our defence operations, and with it the decision to strengthen the operations of HMAS Albatross, a major naval base located in my electorate to the south of Nowra.

A stage 1 budget of $35 million was allocated, providing an influx of capital into the community in the course of this financial year. That will mean more jobs for local residents and businesses. But, more importantly, the government has kept its word on its long‐term commitment to the area by providing capital funding for major works at Albatross for many years to come. The upgrading at Albatross will benefit our community in many ways by the extension to and maintenance of defence personnel housing. In fact, a further 52 houses will be built and/or replaced. These will either be purchased in the local market or built by local operators at an estimated cost of $5½ million. All this contributes to giving the local economy the short‐term kick‐start it so desperately needs and long‐term assurances that any business in the area cannot ignore. I thank the minister and his staff for their efforts to bring about an outcome so beneficial to my community.

I have never subscribed to the view that development must come at the expense of the environment, and neither has this government. To date, some $280,000 has been received for Coastcare projects. I am extremely hopeful that the government's $1 billion National Heritage Trust will directly benefit our environment, with our pristine icon of Jervis Bay, a myriad of waterways and an unsurpassed ecosystem. In fact, the recent announcement of this government's funding of $6.9 million for the Nowra university will see it in operation by the year 2000. We are also quietly confident that our heritage fund will assist in making the technology for Jervis Bay the foundation of ocean medicine development, food cultivation and fish farming.

There are many stakeholders in our coastal environment. They include developers, federal, state and local government, Aboriginal communities, commercial and industrial users and those who earn their living from the coast, such as our fishermen at Ulladulla and surrounding villages. Given such strong and competitive interests and commitment, there is obviously a need to balance these at government and community level. Therefore, I cannot stress enough the importance of a National Heritage Trust for my electorate of Gilmore.

I have spoken in the House before about the level of unemployment in Gilmore. It is no secret that the number of jobless is disproportionately high in our area. This concerns me greatly. However, the message I get in my meetings with both the jobless and small business operators is unchanged: let small business employ, let it expand and create opportunities for the jobless and, above all, help small business remove the industrial shackles imposed by years of Labor neglect.This government has also contributed half a million dollars towards a business incubator in my electorate of Gilmore—another example of small business and the unemployed being recognised by this government. I am simply amazed by Labor's refusal to support our small business by the further reform of unfair dismissal legislation. It is well known that the demands of current unfair dismissal legislation are the biggest deterrents for businesses employing fewer than 15 employees.

BREAK.PARA: The launching of our supermarket to Asia project in the next few months will be yet another incentive for businesses in my electorate. The project will have the clear objective of devising a more effective strategy for marketing the produce of local farmers and businesses. This will be of particular significance to us, as there is no doubt that there is a market for our products in Asia and the Middle East. The supermarket to Asia project will expand our strategy and bring our products to the attention of importers throughout the region. This will be another example of three tiers of government working together for the long‐term prosperity of our community. Still on the topic of investment, as of 1 July what all businesses have asked for is the capital gains tax rollover of funds with the $5 million for reinvestment into other business or for retirement superannuation.

In a perfect world there would be no need for DSS offices in my electorate of Gilmore; everyone would have jobs and no‐one would be in need of government assistance. Unfortunately, a perfect world is still a fair way off. Therefore, with the support of DSS manager David Tagg and his enthusiastic staff, I am pleased to announce that Gilmore has received the go‐ahead for the establishment of a new one‐stop shop DSS. This project is worth over $1 million to our community and again shows this government's commitment to regional Australia.

I have reminded my constituents that it was this government that increased the allowance for carers—of which we have many. On top of that, in Gilmore we have received another 40 aged care places for those who wish to remain at home, with appropriate care, as opposed to going into a nursing home.

Another issue which has raised debate in my electorate is the recent Bringing them home report, which has given all Australians a chance to reflect on our history and the role it plays in defining our national identity. An unfortunate outcome of the report has been a hardening of two philosophical positions. Some endorse what has been referred to as the `black armband' view of our history, focusing on the sins of our forefathers. In so doing, people make no reference to the important and commendable achievements made in 200 years of European civilisation in this country.

There is another school of thought that would have us believe that this history is irrelevant to our everyday lives, that the injustices suffered by our indigenous population are in no way connected to the plight of Gilmore's Aboriginal communities today. Like so many of those that I have spoken to in my electorate, I see myself as somewhere in the middle of the spectrum. What I advocate is a type of compassionate pragmatism and a total and frank recognition of what has happened in Australia, but always with an eye on the best way forward.

Last week, an Aboriginal elder came to speak to me about recent developments. She explained that for her, the stolen generation is an example of history affecting the present. It is a wound that will not heal for many Aboriginal Australians; a pain which cannot be erased and will be part of the identity of indigenous Australians for generations to come. This is something I accept completely. I have no qualms in personally saying, `Sorry', as there is no need to see a personal apology as a recognition of personal responsibility. I was not involved with the tragic events and my personal apology is merely a recognition that Australian history has been kind to me while forcing enormous hardships onto fellow Australians. As politicians, we should be capable of acknowledging the emotional depth of the issues we discuss and responding to such issues with compassion and sensitivity. It is also important that while condemning the practice of the removal of Aboriginal children, we do not overlook the fact that in some cases at least, meaningful and loving relationships were formed between the removed children and their adoptive families.

I now look forward to being part of a government that looks to the future, to the creation of a brighter future for all Australian individuals, and for all of Australia's most needy communities. In conclusion, as I stated earlier, for Gilmore it was certainly a good news budget, one that will create even greater opportunities as we pursue the potential for federation funding and the National Heritage Trust.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fahey, John, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr FAHEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I am pleased to respond to the debate in respect of the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1997‐98 on behalf of the government and the Treasurer (Mr Costello), in particular. I note that some 40 to 45 members of the government have contributed to this debate and supported the budget measures introduced by the Treasurer. What that debate has shown is that there is enormous support from both within this parliament—particularly all members of the government—but more particularly from outside the parliament, from the business sector and from the Australian electorate generally. The reason for that is that, in an economically responsible manner, the budget builds upon and it extends the progress that is being made by the Howard‐Fischer budget some nine months ago.

SPEECH.PARA: First and foremost, this budget is about a fair and equitable approach to the government's accounts. The consolidated measures of the government have turned around a $10.3 billion deficit that was left to us, of course, by Labor and turned it into a sizeable headline surplus in the 1997‐98 budget of some $5 billion and, by 1998‐99, there will be an underlying surplus of $1.6 billion. For the first time in almost a decade—in fact, for the first time this decade—the Minister for Finance did not have to follow the Treasurer on budget night and introduce a loan bill.

The fact is that in this coming year the Commonwealth will repay over $5 billion of government debt. That will free future generations of Australians from the debt associated with servicing the debt that was threatening to drown this particular parliament, this particular government and this particular operation of government. So successful is the government's strategy of addressing the overall structure of the budget that it has been estimated that in the period since the government came into office until the year 2000‐2001, the Commonwealth's net debt to GDP ratio will almost halve. This will ensure that Australians can face the new millennium in the knowledge that the country's future has been secured. The remarkable turnaround has occurred without having to increase taxes, be it income tax, company tax, wholesale sales tax, or for that matter, excise on petrol.

Despite the difficulties faced in addressing the structural problems in the budget left to us by Labor, we have been able to introduce a number of initiatives in this budget. I will just add a couple of those initiatives. We have introduced, for the first time by an Australian government, a broadly based savings rebate; improvements in the superannuation arrangements and the tightening of rules governing access to superannuation prior to retirement; the provision of greater choice about where Australians can invest their superannuation contributions; the introduction of a deferred pension bonus plan for older Australians; a commitment to maintain the pension at 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings; and the increase in the ordinary domiciliary nursing care benefit to align it with the child disability allowance.

BREAK.PARA: Other features include: additional funding of $54 million under the Commonwealth‐state disability agreement; improvements to entry level training incentive payments designed to encourage employers to take on apprentices and trainees; introduction of the work for the dole scheme; building on the government's commitment to reduce compliance costs for small business by streamlining the withholding tax arrangements; and the doubling of the deduction under the income test for second and subsequent children to allow more families access to Austudy.

Yet more features include: an additional $76 million to increase our quarantine capacity and improve our quarantine service; the provision of $1.25 billion for expenditure by the Natural Heritage Trust over the next six years; and the creation of the Federation Fund to finance major projects of national significance to mark the centenary of Federation and to contribute to many of Australia's infrastructure needs for the coming century.

In summary, the budget builds upon the strategy begun in last year's budget to turn around Australia's financial position and to provide the framework to accelerate the pace of sustainable economic growth, the creation of real job opportunities and the maintenance of a regime of lower interest rates. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The original question was that this bill be now read a second time. To this, the honourable Deputy Leader of the Opposition has moved as an amendment that all words after `that' be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The question now is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question.

—As it is necessary to resolve this question to enable further questions to be considered in relation to this bill, in accordance with standing order 277, the bill will be returned to the House for further consideration.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 6.32 p.m. to 8 p.m.

BREAK.PARA: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Mossfield) took the chair at 8 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 May, on motion by Mr Fahey:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am here this evening representing the shadow treasurer, who is not able to respond on behalf of the opposition at this time. The main problem the Labor Party has with the budget strategy is its reliance on failed economic dogma. It very much reflects the coalition's wasted years in opposition and its inability to fashion a reform program outside the shortcomings of orthodox economic theory.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1997‐98 and its budget strategy, it is very clear that a measure of the government's failure comes from its own determination to hold out tax reform as something of a distraction to the way in which the budget has been received around the country. When people look back on the 1997 budget, there is no doubt that, more than anything else, they will remember the tax concessions and savings incentives that are mainly for the rich in Australia.

BREAK.PARA: They will remember the determination of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to move public attention onto the question of a GST instead of the government going through the normal process of moving around the country to provide confidence in the economic strategy.

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 8.02 p.m. to 8.15 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the one minute and 24 seconds I had prior to the division, I was demolishing the government's budget strategy and exposing its many flaws. Now, thankfully, I have been advised that the main purpose of this debate is to address capital outlays in the budget, so having dispensed with the general strategy I can move to the more specific.

BREAK.PARA: There is an item out of my electorate that is a capital works of great waste. The fact that the government in this budget and, I believe, in earlier budgets has been allocating funds for the construction of a hospital, an important capital facility, at the Holsworthy army base is an appropriation that needs to be questioned, more so with the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) present in the Main Committee chamber. How wasteful it is for a government to be outlaying some $20 million on the construction of a hospital at Holsworthy when the government also has these grievous plans for the construction of Sydney's second international airport on the same site.

When this proposition was first raised, I had a concern that the hospital might in fact be adept forward planning; the idea that, with all that unexploded ordnance around at Holsworthy, the first plane that would land at such an airport may well require a modern, state of the art hospital nearby for the looming catastrophe. If the government is engaging in that sort of forward planning, I would ask them to desist. There is a better way to handle this matter, of course, and that is not to engage in the folly of Holsworthy, and to allow the $20 million to be well spent.

I am sure the military hospital relocated out of my electorate, at Ingleburn, to the seat of Hughes, at the Holsworthy base, is a needed facility. There is no doubt about that. But it has to be a facility that is used for military purposes, not to literally mop up the tragedy of bad planning and bad decision making in relation to the site of Sydney's second international airport. I know, in making those comments, that that is a proposition that the Minister for Finance would support for two reasons. One is: why waste $20 million on the construction of a hospital when the government also has a plan for an airport? But I also know—and this is the second reason—that he is busting out of his skin to actually say something about Holsworthy and engage himself in the public debate. The only thing that is stopping him is said to be the release of the EIS.

Why someone needs an EIS to tell them that an international airport with two 4,000‐metre runways directed at large residential areas is a problem, I am yet to work out. But if the Minister for Finance can just use a bit of logic in this matter, and understand that his constituents are screaming for representation and screaming for him to say something about Holsworthy, maybe this issue of the capital outlay for the hospital is his entree to that particular debate. So, as Minister for Finance and member for Macarthur, at long last he can find a legitimate reason to enter the Holsworthy debate, to actually represent the people in his electorate who are so concerned, and to do it in a fiscally responsible fashion. That is, to say that the capital outlay for the hospital would be wasted if the airport goes ahead and the hospital and other major facilities need to be demolished, and that this is a poor allocation of Commonwealth funding.

It is an issue that is alive in the south west of Sydney and, indeed, throughout the region of greater western Sydney, as you would appreciate, Mr Deputy Speaker. Of all the crazy things that have been said and done in relation to the Holsworthy site, there is nothing more absurd than spending scarce public funds on a hospital, knowing that the allocation of a site for the airport at Holsworthy could lead to the demolition of that facility. With all the hospital needs, the health care needs and the capital facilities that are required around Australia, how wasteful it is for the government to be allocating that money and having the prospect of folly being held out by the site of Sydney's second international airport.

The whole question of capital funding in the health area is also critical out of this budget, because there is a clear instance of folly, cost shifting and resource shifting in the way in which the government is holding out $500 million worth of incentives for private health insurance, but at the same time is dramatically reducing, I think by $800 million, the funding that is going through to the states for hospitals. So right across the board, and with the hospital funding at Holsworthy and the misuse of those resources, there is a need for the member for Macarthur to launch himself into the debate on behalf of his constituents, and to do so in a fiscally responsible fashion.

This is your clear entree. Come into the debate, represent your electorate and say that it is a bad waste of the $20 million to go ahead with an airport when the hospital is just being completed at Holsworthy. But you should also recognise that, in the south‐west of Sydney, there is a sad legacy of the period of the Fahey state government. Hospital resources are so inadequate throughout the region because they would not do anything about the reallocation of capital resources in health from the centre of Sydney to where they are needed on Sydney's fringe—the great population region. So here is Labor again having to tidy up all the problems that were caused by mismanagement by the Fahey state government and now by lack of representation by the honourable member in the federal parliament. I am here tidying these things up and giving the best advice I can on all sorts of matters—

TALK.START.PARA: —And doing very well.

—On Appropriation Bill (No. 2)—capital funding, health, aviation policies—it is all there in a nice package, plus the demolition of the budget strategy at large. I do not think I could add to those remarks in any way possible at this time. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
—The debate is adjourned. The member will have leave to continue his remarks at a later date.
—In accordance with standing order 226, the Main Committee will first consider the schedule of the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles, Chris, MP

The consideration of the items in groups of departments has met the convenience of the House and the Main Committee in past years. I also take the opportunity to indicate to the Main Committee that the proposed order for consideration of departments' estimates has been discussed with the opposition and independent members and there has been no objection to what is proposed.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed expenditure, $1,046,985,000.
Proposed expenditure, $2,868,893,000.
Proposed expenditure, $505,327,000.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Advance to the Minister for Finance

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed expenditure, $215,000,000.
Proposed expenditure, $20,000,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this set of expenditures, I mention that contained in the last amount of money is provision for the administration of the Taxation Office and I wish to make some comments about the saving scheme contained in this year's budget.

BREAK.PARA: As I indicated in my second reading speech, on the evidence of the Secretary of the Treasury to the Senate estimates committee, the Treasury has indicated—unlike the Treasurer—that perhaps there is some doubt about the potential effectiveness of the scheme as proposed, in that it may not have the required outcome on national savings. I wish to take this opportunity to talk about the saving scheme in relation to my electorate because I believe that it is a sick joke that will do nothing for the majority of my constituents. The latest available figures released by the Australian Taxation Office show that half of the taxpayers in Lalor, Thomastown and Epping—suburbs within my electorate—did not earn any interest from savings at all. These people will get no savings rebate whatsoever.

Those people who had savings which earned interest earned an average of $492. This translates into an average annual rebate of $74 per year—about $1.40 a week, or less than 20c a day. This I believe to be a sad joke. Perhaps my constituents will be able to put this pathetic amount towards their child‐care costs, which will increase because of cuts in this area. Perhaps they will be able to put it towards the increased costs of their medication because of the changes to the PBS.

Perhaps they can put the 20c towards the nursing home entry charges for their parents that this government seeks to introduce. Perhaps it can be used towards their fee for employment services, which the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, seeks to introduce. Half of these people will receive an average rebate of 20c; the other half will receive nothing. This savings initiative is nothing but a shameful hoax.

It is all the more contemptible because it comes at the expense of superannuation contributions which would have assisted these people in retirement and would have achieved a great deal towards boosting national savings. Those in their mid‐30s on average weekly earnings who are lucky enough to get the 20c a day must be aware that it comes at the expense of $110,000 from their retirement income packages—that is, $110,000 less towards national savings.

In putting together the statistics for the suburbs in my electorate, I was particularly disappointed to find that the Australian Taxation Office no longer gives the type of detail by postcode that it used to. I believe that, in the interests of meaningful analysis, the ATO should attempt to present the statistics in such a way that they are easily able to be compared.

It is also interesting that, since the bringing down of the budget by the Treasurer, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has gone into his kitbag of emergency notions to try to deflect from other issues and grabbed at tax reform, but tax reform in the minds of this government is a code for the introduction of a GST. At the time when a GST was previously proposed, it was contended by the proposers that a consumption tax in some way leads to an increase in national savings on the basis that, because it is a tax on consumption, people will be less likely to consume and, therefore, spend money and thus retain savings.

The people in the suburbs that I mentioned earlier have very little non‐discretionary expenditure. They will not be able not to decide to buy the things that they need for day‐to‐day living and, therefore, there will be no effect on national savings because of those people's expenditure and spending patterns. I believe that as the debate continues on the goods and services tax—because that appears to be the major plank that the government proposes to raise as part of its tax reform package—we will need to look at the experiences in other countries that have shown that these types of GSTs have not had the proposed effect on savings.

The debate that we are going to see about a GST is not a substitute for the government looking at policies in the area of employment. The GST and the types of tax reforms that the government is going to propose in the lead‐up to the next election do nothing for the creation of jobs or to give people a greater sense of job security. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I acknowledge the attendance in the Main Committee of the Acting Prime Minister, Mr Tim Fischer, and the Minister for Finance, Mr Fahey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis, Ralph, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address my remarks in the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1997‐98 to the foreign aid allocation for 1997‐98 and, in particular, to the allocation for Africa. It is deplorable that for the second year under the Liberal government the ODA vote has been reduced in nominal terms and that it has been cut in real terms by 12.6 per cent over the past two years. As a percentage of GDP, it has fallen from 0.31 per cent to 0.27 per cent in that time—the lowest level for several decades. But even more deplorable is the cut in aid to Africa, aid which has been reduced in nominal terms from $108.7 million in 1995‐96 to $87.7 million in 1997‐98—a cut of $21 million or 19.3 per cent. In real terms, this amounts to a cut of 22.7 per cent. That is a reduction of almost one‐quarter in just two years—almost double the real cut in total aid.

SPEECH.PARA: Why was Africa singled out for especially severe treatment? The government, through its minister or in its budget papers, gives no explanation except to try to excuse the cut by pointing to the IDA contribution to the World Bank and saying that, as 40 per cent of the International Development Association funds are allocated to Africa, 40 per cent of our IDA contribution for 1997‐98 of $121.5 million will be spent in Africa, resulting in a total Australian contribution to Africa of $140 million. However, this excuse ignores the fact that this point is true every year and that the allocation for IDA this year is actually $6 million less than for the previous year. The $140 million figure is also a rounding‐up of an actual figure of $136.3 million.

The reality is that there is no excuse for cutting funds to Africa, especially not to a greater degree than the cut to aid overall. This is especially so if, as the minister claims in his foreword to the budget paper on page xi under the heading of Australia's overseas aid program 1997‐98, the principal objectives of Australia's aid program should be to ensure the reduction of poverty and the promotion of economic development as a permanent means of overcoming such poverty. If those are the principal objectives of the government's aid, how can it possibly justify slashing funds by one‐quarter for the poorest continent in the world, the continent experiencing the greatest difficulty in achieving economic development?

Just look at the facts: 33 of the 48 least developed countries in the world are in Africa. Most of these countries have a GDP per capita of less than $US2 per day. Indeed, World Bank figures show that, in 1993, there were 219 million people in sub‐Saharan Africa—40 per cent of the region's population—living on less than $US1 per day, and that that number had increased by 40 million in the six years up to 1993. In regard to poverty, Africa, especially sub‐Saharan Africa, is clearly well qualified for our aid.

With regard to economic development, Africa's economic performance has been very poor until the past year or so. Over the 15 years from 1980‐94, real GDP per capita for Africa declined by 15 per cent. Many African countries now have a level of real income per head less than in 1970. Although economic growth has improved in the past year or two—with an overall growth rate of five per cent in 1996 and a similar outcome expected this year—these rates of growth are nowhere near high enough to make a marked impact on widespread poverty. As World Bank Vice‐President Madavo said in Nairobi last month, what is needed is rates of growth of eight to 10 per cent if Africa is to eradicate crippling poverty. Clearly, that is not going to happen. World Bank forecasts are for growth in sub‐Saharan Africa to be 3½ to four per cent in the near future.

A major debilitating impediment to growth in many African countries is their extremely high levels of foreign debt and official debt. Of the 41 most indebted poor countries in the world in 1994, 27 had a foreign debt to GDP ratio of over 100 per cent, and 21 of those countries were African. Furthermore, 13 of those 27 countries—12 of them African—had scheduled interest payments on government borrowings of over 100 per cent of government revenue. Obviously, they cannot allocate anywhere near 100 per cent of revenue to their debt servicing, so their debt mounts inexorably and their financial predicament becomes even more excruciating.

Of course, such countries obtain virtually no benefit from rapidly expanding private capital flows to developing countries, flows which all go to a handful of countries. Sub‐Saharan Africa got 3.6 per cent of foreign direct investment to developing countries in 1994. Accordingly, the foreign aid allocation for Africa is highly unrepresentative of the need for economic development in that region. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis, Colin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on these appropriations for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and I am pleased to see in the chamber the Minister for Trade and Acting Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer). We are all conscious of the very important role he plays as the Minister for Trade.

SPEECH.PARA: Of particular concern to me are the savage cuts that have been imposed on the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade by this budget. I know it is always difficult as you are dealing with competing interests, but I cannot see why we have closed our mission in Copenhagen. It played a very important role not only in Denmark but also in the other countries that it had responsibility for. I suppose this will be an extra burden now on the post in Sweden until they close that mission. I had always hoped that at some time we would be able to open an office in Helsinki and in that way deal with some of the countries nearby, such as Latvia. That hope, I suppose, is now fading even further.

We have also closed our post in Nauru, not that that would have brought much here, but it sent an important message. What we are doing by cutting funds to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is sending all the wrong messages about Australia's interest in the area. The member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) spoke very eloquently about the cut to foreign aid to Africa. I notice in front of me the excellent report prepared by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade entitled Australia's relations with Southern Africa. I was the chair of that committee until the election and so someone else had the honour of bringing it down.

The committee put a lot of work into that report and it has been very well received, not only here but also in Africa. We highlighted many of the points that the member for Gellibrand was making about poverty in Africa. Although we were dealing with the SADC countries, we had hoped that in bringing down that report we would rekindle Australia's declining interest in Africa. We made much, during the apartheid years, of our interest in southern Africa. However, since democracy has come to South Africa we seem to be withdrawing from there and not showing any interest at all.

BREAK.PARA: Apart from the cut to aid, my other concern is the cut to funds for population programs. I had hoped that we would restore funding to the IPPF and to the United Nations Fund for Population and Development that was so savagely and severely cut in last year's budget. At a time when Australia was increasing its funding in that area, we came in and cut massive amounts of money from those two programs. Although we did not cut more this time, neither did we put extra funds in there. I thought that at some time the cuts last year, savage as they were, would have only been a temporary measure and we would have started to redress the balance.

These population programs are important, especially to our near neighbours in the Pacific. We are sending all the wrong messages. I said that last year, and nothing has changed my mind. We are sending the wrong messages to those Pacific countries. We are indicating to them that Australia does not care, that Australia has no concern for them.

The one issue that I and everyone I speak to cannot understand is the cut to Radio Australia. Why do it? Minister, you more than most of us would know the important role that Radio Australia plays throughout Asia. It is not expensive—a couple of posts at a mission would pay for it. However, once we cut that service it will never recover. Do not think that by us cutting our radio service that there is not going to be a service there. The Brits are coming in, as are the French and the Chinese. Many nations are trying to come in there.

At the very time when other countries are coming in and when Australia is making much of our relationship with Asia, we are cutting the cheapest and most effective way of getting across our message to Asia about what Australia is and what it stands for. We are doing that by cutting funds to Radio Australia. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis, Ralph, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, further to my earlier remarks, I want to indicate that I believe there is another reason why we should be maintaining, if not increasing, funds to Africa. That is, that this region, apart from being poor and having great trouble in establishing economic development, is currently facing the scourge of HIV/AIDS in a devastating way.

SPEECH.PARA: Consider these facts: in October 1996 the UN estimated that, for the whole world, six million people have died of AIDS and that there are 22 million people currently living with HIV/AIDS, which number is increasing by 8,500 a day or 3.1 million a year. Of that 22 million, 21 million are adults, over 40 per cent of them women, and one million are children—most of whom have been HIV infected in their mother's womb or, post‐birth, infected by their mother's milk.

Despite the concern this disease has created in developed countries, it is the developing countries, which account for 90 per cent of HIV/AIDS sufferers, which have the real problem. Nowhere is this more true than in sub‐Saharan Africa where 13 million people have HIV/AIDS—that is, about 60 per cent of the world total. The extent of this epidemic in a number of sub‐Saharan countries is absolutely devastating. For instance, in Zambia, out of a population of 9.4 million, it was estimated in 1995 that 1½ million people were HIV positive—that is, 17 per cent of the population. This did not include full‐blown AIDS sufferers. One in three of the population aged between 15 and 50 was HIV positive.

In Botswania, population 1.4 million, an estimated 180,000 people, or 13 per cent of the population, were HIV positive. In Zimbabwe, population 10.9 million, there were an estimated one million HIV positive cases, or nine per cent of the population and one in four of the age group 15 to 50. In Malawi, population 9.6 million, an estimated one million people were HIV positive—over 10 per cent of the population. By way of comparison, Australia, with a population of 18 million, has about 11,000 people currently living with HIV/AIDS—that is, 0.06 per cent of the population.

The impact of this pandemic on the sub‐Sahara is already severe and will become more so as the vast numbers of HIV infected people become AIDS sufferers. Apart from the great increase in human suffering and loss of life, there are extremely serious social, economic and even potentially political consequences from this holocaust. Family life is being devastated by the death of parents, with many children ending up in crowded orphanages or becoming homeless street kids in the cities. Families are forced into debt and poverty through the extra health cost they have to bear and the loss of productive family members.

Education levels are being reduced through the inability of stricken families to afford school fees or because children are needed to earn a living or to care for the sick, and also because of the deaths of many teachers. The health system of these countries is being overwhelmed. In Zimbabwe, in many hospitals over half of the beds are taken up with sufferers from HIV‐related illnesses.

The economies of these countries are also being severely affected. Large additional costs are imposed on the economy through the need to fund prevention programs, as well as greatly increased health costs to care for those infected. This puts great pressure on already strained, if not overwhelmed, budgets and crowds out any other necessary expenditures for social and economic development.

Furthermore, with the disease concentrated on the most productive age group, the widespread loss of skilled personnel is reducing both the quantity and quality of labour. This is especially the case for white‐collar professionals, which group has the highest incidence of infection. Accordingly, these countries are losing many of their most skilled managerial and professional people in business, the public service, teaching and academia. Even parliaments are severely affected. For instance, in Zambia, which has a parliament of 155 seats, there have been 22 by‐elections in the last two years due to deaths, of which 20 are thought to be AIDS related. Thus, institutional infrastructures and the quality of government are at risk of being undermined by the loss of such personnel.

So too are the enterprises of these nations which face continual loss of their key personnel and management, loss of productivity through employees being ill on the job or absent because of their illness or the illness of other family members. The impact on some industries will be absolutely staggering. In Zambia, a study of the copper industry several years ago showed 60 per cent of the labour force in the industry were HIV positive—this in an industry which accounts for 90 per cent of Zambian exports and 25 per cent of its GDP. Exports from these countries will also be adversely affected by the impact of HIV/AIDS on agriculture and the likely diversion of tourism to less risky destinations.

However, the statistic that perhaps best sums up the horrific nature of what is happening in these countries is UNDP's estimate that, without AIDS, African life expectancy would have been 62 years by the year 2000, but with AIDS it is expected to be only 47 years. How, one may ask, in the face of such a total calamity, can we in all conscience slash our aid to these countries? But that is what we have done. Shame on those who are responsible!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer, Tim, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, this is my maiden speech as a minister in this particular chamber. At the outset I want to say that I acknowledge the sincerity of the views held by the member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) and the contribution he made to this estimates hearing, and also the sincerity of the views of the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis).

SPEECH.PARA: In response to those views let me say that it is never easy, given the challenges of government, to work through an exact allocation of priorities within each portfolio and between portfolios. I am sure the member for Gellibrand can well recall during his previous ministerial positions when in government just how difficult that process can be. You do have to make judgments on priorities. You do have to arrive at the right conclusions with regard to program allocations.

This year Australia's aid budget under the provisions of this budget will be $1.430 billion. In the tight budgetary circumstances, as we build towards a surplus in next year's budget, this represents a decrease of only one per cent on the estimated 1996‐97 outlays. It is a large amount of money; it is $1.430 billion. Yes, it has been shaved over the last two years and had we not been left with the huge Beazley $8 billion plus black hole, we would not have had to embark on this path.

We are very conscious of the need to proceed with care. I take particular note of the comments of the member for Gellibrand with regard to the plague proportions and crisis proportions of AIDS and HIV. They are indeed very startling figures which he presented to the committee here tonight.

The AusAid budget is a large budget, one carefully allocated and with a particular focus on countries in south Asia and other parts of Asia which are closer to home. That does not ignore completely the circumstances of Africa. As the member for Gellibrand has acknowledged, there is a continuing allocation, but it is one which he would like to see increased. I can only say that the government has, in the circumstances, done as much as it can do. Of course, we will continue to provide, through multilateral arrangements, additional aid with regard to HIV-AIDS worldwide.

Turning to the comments of the member for Throsby, the closure of the Copenhagen and Nauru missions were difficult decisions, to be frank, and were ones which I know were carefully weighed by my colleague, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Alexander Downer, and myself and others before reaching that conclusion.

In respect of Copenhagen I would point out that there are posts elsewhere in Europe in Athens, Belgrade, Berlin, Bonn, Brussels, Budapest, Dublin, Holy See, London, Madrid, Malta, Moscow, Nicosia, Paris, Rome, Stockholm, The Hague, Vienna and Warsaw. Locating posts involves getting the right balance between various parts of the world and within various regions of the world. It was not a decision taken lightly. Governments, from time to time, close posts, and governments, from time to time, open posts. For example, we have picked up on your decision of a couple of years back to reopen Beirut in Lebanon and retain that post. It is an important post in the Middle East.

I note his comments with regard to Radio Australia that an additional $4 million was supplied from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to recover in part the reductions in budget allocation to Radio Australia. Radio Australia does have an important role to play. The real enemies of Radio Australia, I have since discovered, rested in the senior echelons of the ABC. If it were not for elements within the ABC and their agenda against Radio Australia, we would not have been presented with the shutdown circumstance we were confronted with. However, we have dealt with that, turned it around, and we have provided now for a continuing operation of Radio Australia, albeit on a reduced scale.

BREAK.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, I commend the estimate to the committee. I thank the member for Gellibrand and the member for Throsby for their deeply held views which they presented to the committee tonight. I also say to members of the committee, especially as they examine the trade side of things, to study the trade outcomes and objectives statement which I tabled at the start of this year. It gives a very good overview of our trading circumstance and it has a statistical backup.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis, Ralph, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, first let me say that we do not accept that the budgetary position excuses the cut in aid. The budget deficit that was left by the former government was one of the lowest budget deficits in the Western developed world, as was the level of government debt; and neither of those circumstances in any way justify cutting aid to people in tremendous need.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have a bit more time now, I want to refer to a particular cut that was made in the budget in relation to a program which was advertised to non‐government organisations last August. It was called the ANGOP, which I think is the African and non‐government organisations program, and it has now been axed. But in February 1997, AusAID wrote to the Australian NGOs requesting project ideas by mid‐April for a program that it had announced after last year's budget. They received 48 proposals. All the NGOs acted in good faith and put a great deal of effort and planning into the proposals. This work was matched by others in Africa, where communities and their leaders had also done a lot of work discussing and planning the types of projects which would respond to the needs of local communities.

AusAID was due to announce the successful projects in the week after the budget was brought down. However, the NGO representatives were told, as part of a briefing on the night of the budget, that the program had been cancelled as a result of budget cuts. So a program was announced at the time of the last budget. Everyone worked like hell on it from August last year to May this year, and on the night of the budget they were told that all that was a waste, it was gone. This was not only work by people in the NGOs here in Australia, with their scarce resources allocated to working up good projects, but also work by people in Africa who had been very much involved in trying to work up those projects so that they were good, decent projects.

World Vision has said that six of their projects have been axed as a result of the wiping of the scheme. They were: in Ethiopia, a project to improve the health of 41,000 people through clean water and improved sanitation; in Malawi, a project to provide HIV/AIDS education and home based care support to 62,000 people; in Malawi, a project to improve seed supply and to increase farm yields and food security for 30,000 people; in Uganda, a project to help 10,000 people affected by HIV/AIDS; in Mozambique, a project to improve the health of 20,000 people by improving water supply and sanitation facilities; and, in Mozambique, another project to improve the health of 37,000 people through improved water supply and sanitation facilities. That was just one NGO with six proposals. There were 48 altogether.

The wiping of this program, announced in the last budget and knocked off on budget night this year, wipes out a whole raft of very decent projects which have been worked on assiduously by the NGOs. It has been a total waste of their time and effort in producing these projects and a total waste of the time and effort of a lot of people in Africa who have got better things to do in trying to make something of their lives than muck around with aid projects that do not come to anything.I think that has been a quite deplorable development.

BREAK.PARA: In the report referred to by the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), Australia's relations with Southern Africa, which was produced by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade last year, there are lots of recommendations, including recommendations for good governance. That is very important in Africa. There is no point in us just saying that we have got to hand money over to them to waste because they do not have good governing and administrative procedures. We want to make sure there are good administration and good governance principles applying in the various nations of that continent, and there are recommendations in that report for that to happen.

In the case of Zimbabwe, for instance, a number of people have come to this country from the parliament and there have been quite beneficial impacts from what was called the small activities scheme and the good governance program that was run under that. But, as a result of this budget, that scheme was knocked on the head. So there will be no more in the way of us helping to improve good governance in Africa through that program. That is just deplorable. It is tremendously wasteful.

This is an area which everyone agrees is fundamental. We say to the Africans, `You've got to lift your own game. We're not going to keep giving you aid unless you operate properly, get rid of corruption, lift your performance in terms of your economy, make sure you apply democratic principles, et cetera.' But when you have got programs directed to that, to good governance, and you wipe them, how can you possibly justify that? It just goes against all commonsense and against the report of the joint committee. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dargavel, Steven, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My question goes to trade and the emergence of the Internet as a potential market for small business in the country and in my electorate. One of the inhibitors of small business and commerce on the Internet is the concerns that consumers have about the security of commercial transactions. It is relatively easy for an informed Net nerd to intercept e‐mails and commercial transactions. This has led to a serious concern and a lack of consumer confidence in commercial transactions.

SPEECH.PARA: Into this problem area emerges a company called Nexus, which has developed an encryption product which has been widely recognised in the industry as second to none. It is a 448‐bit key encryption product which takes about 2,000 to 3,000 years to decrypt using a high‐end conventional PC. Such an excellent encryption product has caused security organisations some concern, because it infringes on their assumed right to peruse the personal e‐mails and transactions of citizens. Consequently, the government has refused to award Nexus an export licence after the company had landed a very significant contract with the World Health Organisation.

Frankly, it is beyond me to know why the Australian government feels it necessary for their intelligence organisation to have the capability of inspecting the internal e‐mails of the World Health Organisation. Nonetheless, it goes beyond a debate simply about whether intelligence organisations should be able to decrypt the private e‐mails of citizens in Australia to citizens elsewhere. This is a debate about whether people have confidence in the Internet as a forum for commercial transactions. Australia has one of the highest take‐up rates of technology in the world. Because of that, arguably, Australian business stands to lose the most, because of the lack of consumer confidence in the Internet as a vehicle for doing business.

My concern with what has happened to this particular company with their product goes beyond simply the disadvantage caused to this company by the limiting of the export of its product. It goes to the potential that Australian business has of exploiting the emerging opportunities presented on the Internet. This particular company, apart from being denied an export licence, asked what it would take to get permission to sell its product to Australian government departments. It was told that, if its software were vetted by an organisation, it could go on the list. The government has outsourced the vetting process to a private sector company—coincidentally, a company which also engages in the marketing of encryption software. It eventuates that the company that also markets encryption software has said that it will take a great deal of time to assess this particular company's software and that will cost the very small business in Australia some $250,000. This is a small business that is trying to pitch a product at under $250 per unit per twin‐site licence. So, in that environment, you have a small business that really has to do better than a company like BHP to make itself worth while.

To add insult to injury, in the system that the government is asking this company to go through, it is required to hand over its source code to the American private sector company—to vet it on behalf of the Australian government! Quite a situation, clearly, and one that is not sustainable. In my view, it is inconsistent with the self‐professed ideology of members opposite that talks about the rights of the individual—the rights to privacy, the rights to individual freedoms and so on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins, Harry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the committee for very long. I acknowledge the generous amount of time that the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) has given to the Main Committee, which reflects his capacities as a parliamentarian and, even though I might not agree with him as a politician, I respect him as a parliamentarian.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to express briefly my concern about the climate change debate in Australia and Australia's attitude to it internationally. Whilst I realise that the meetings that will happen very soon, following the G7 meeting and the so‐called Rio II, will not necessarily lock everybody in, they are very important in the run‐up to the Kyoto conference in December.

We have to get the balance right. I acknowledge that this has to be a whole‐of‐government approach to a fairly important question, but I also note that on page 52 of the portfolio budget statement of the department it says:
Directions and outcomes of key international environment negotiations which safeguard or advance Australian economic, environmental and other interests . . .

When we talk about `other interests' in this debate, we should not just talk about trade and industry interests alone; we should balance them against not only the world's environmental interests, but also Australia's environmental interests because, as I have said before, the environmental problems that the world has know no geopolitical boundaries. We have to keep that in consideration.

The other thing I wish to touch upon briefly—and I know that the Acting Prime Minister, in his capacity as the Minister for Trade, has made his views pretty clear on this—is social clauses in trade agreements, whether they be multilateral agreements or bilateral agreements. Australia's role is to show leadership on these questions. It is in Australia's interests to develop some of these questions through trade agreements.

One social matter that I have raised from time to time in this place is the question of child labour. This is a difficult problem for a number of countries within which child labour is practised. It is a very important problem for the economies of families and the like, but this is something on which Australia, in the best interests of Australia as a nation, needs to show leadership.

BREAK.PARA: I appreciate that, as Minister for Trade, the Acting Prime Minister has made his position clear. I note that that position does not necessarily deviate greatly from that of previous trade ministers, even in Labor governments. This is an ongoing debate that we continue to need to have. It is in Australia's interests to enter into these debates with countries, either at a multilateral level or at a bilateral level.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer, Tim, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade and Acting Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis), the member for Fraser (Mr Dargavel) and the member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) for their additional contributions.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to NGOs, I advise the member for Gellibrand that additional funds of $3 million have been allocated to the AusAID NGO cooperation program, whereby government funds are used to subsidise the fundraising of the NGOs. This represents a real increase of 17 per cent, or nearly 20 per cent in nominal terms, on that aspect of the equation. I am honest enough to say that that is only a very small aspect, because total funding available to NGOs in the next budget will decrease to around $88 million, compared with $102 million.

However, AusAID expenditure is still maintained at $1.4 billion. That is a fairly big‐ticket item in a budget which has to be carefully weighed on all items. This is overseas expenditure. I often find myself in a hall having to argue about why we give any foreign aid. There is a great deal of logic, quite apart from humanitarian reasons, as to why we give foreign aid, and I will always defend a sensible, efficient, and effective foreign aid program. However, I take particular note of the member for Gellibrand's comments and they will be referred to AusAID.

With regard to the member for Fraser, I invite him to give the names of the companies in respect of export and the Internet matter to Mr David Crook, an officer from Austrade who is here tonight. We will try to follow up that issue.

With regard to the member for Scullin, I value his comments. On climate change, the tide has actually been turning a little in the last few days. A report in the United States from the energy department is putting a more realistic tilt on the whole business of uniform targets which elements of Europe and the United States would seek to impose, and which would so disadvantage our GDP and coal jobs in the Hunter Valley, Central Queensland and elsewhere.

I am pleased that when I went to the OECD Energy Ministers' Conference we persuaded the Europeans to sign up to a communique which says that targets should be achievable and realistic and take into account each country's particular circumstance.

Of course the environment of the planet earth is a fragile circumstance; of course it extends beyond national boundaries. Yes, we will make a genuine and cooperative effort towards Kyoto and an achievement of something that is going to be practical, realistic and something which will engage the developing countries, not just the developed countries—and that is also a part of getting the equation right. But I am not and the federal government is not of a mind to go down some suicide economic path which in turn would ultimately add to the greenhouse gas emissions problem. We must carefully weigh this. We are proceeding to fight and put forward our diplomatic representations and, in fact, we are gaining some support. Recently, Norway has joined with Australia and hopefully there are others to come.

On the social causes and child labour, it is unacceptable that in the 1990s anywhere in the world there is slave child labour with its horrific abuse of children. I must say that I feel most strongly about it as did Michael Duffy, a former minister, who was part of a report which was completed just at the change of government last year. But we have the International Labour Organisation (ILO). I know the minister follows Geneva with interest and I am pleased to see the Minister for Industrial Relations here. I actually looked up their budget the other day. I called for a one-page summary of their budget. The ILO budget is in excess of half a billion US dollars.

My beef simply is that there is an organisation called the International Labour Organisation and it should get on with the task of doing, among other things, all that it ought to be doing with regard to child labour. I do not believe that it sits happily in the World Trade Organisation arena. The correct way to carry it forward is in the ILO and I have discussed this previously with the Minister for Industrial Relations. I nevertheless agree that this abuse of children anywhere in the 1990s is absolutely unacceptable as is the fact that the Internet is being abused for child pornography purposes. Again, that was pursued by Foreign Affairs and Trade and by me in the OECD setting just two weeks ago. I do thank members for their thoughtful contributions to this estimates debate for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I believe that on balance, the budget and its allocations are fair but there is a challenge and that is to get the most effective use of all the taxpayers' dollars allocated.(Time expired)
Proposed expenditure agreed to.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Department of Primary Industries and Energy

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed expenditure, $435,682,000

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andren, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In my main budget speech I detailed several aspects of the rural scene that demanded urgent attention from this government and which were not addressed in the budget.

SPEECH.PARA: Happily, the government has seen fit to extend exceptional circumstances coverage for an additional three months for those whose coverage was due to run out in early June. However, with a new or a renewed drought hitting the tablelands of New South Wales and other parts of Australia, despite some recent falls there will be no pasture growth this winter and precious little run‐off. Despite this help there needs to be a further review of this three months assistance and, in the longer term, I support the views of New South Wales Farmers Association which is not prepared to endorse any wholesale modifications to the overall drought assistance measures until full details are available which provide for transitional arrangements.

The farm sector is looking forward to the government's integrated rural policy package to be announced later this year which was forecast in the budget. The rhetoric is fine but the delivery of this package is vital to achieve its aims and I certainly hope such lofty aims will be achieved.
Let me quote from the budget papers.

The integrated policy package will draw upon several reviews of Commonwealth rural policy undertaken recently and the government will consult with stakeholders, industry groups and states before finalising elements of the policy later in the year.

The objective of this package is to promote a self‐reliant productive rural sector supported by targeted government measures which focus on building the skills and capacity of rural industries and communities to manage effectively in an uncertain environment.
The environment is certainly uncertain. I notice that the National Rural Finance Summit Activating Committee will have an input into this package.

In the main chamber the other night, I mentioned the plight of farmers in my electorate faced with a lending regime of banks that are charging usury rates, denying access to small business loans, and certainly not helping build the skills of participants in this part of rural industry. These views were aired by farmers, small businessmen and rural councillors at the Bathurst Bank Forum last Wednesday.

There must be alternative avenues for farm finance and the government must be proactive in supporting such measures and, if necessary, underwriting where proposals are sound. It is one thing to talk about self‐reliance in the farming sector; it is another to expect the farm sector to carry all the risks.

The sort of support I envisage is tax breaks, rebates or credits for farmers for drought‐proofing properties or for those contractors involved in such provisions as haymaking. The Premier of New South Wales suggested this idea to the Prime Minister recently. That is interesting, as I provided Mr Carr with a copy of my first speech in this parliament—at his request—which included that very idea. It may not have been original, but I suspect that is where the Premier got the idea, and I am happy to share it with him and anyone else. I also hope the rural package to be announced later this year addresses the farm assets question for an intergenerational transfer of farms because that, too, is continuing to cause hardship.

The supermarket to Asia strategy means nothing if we do not help improve the infrastructure to export our produce. It is interesting to note the recent unveiling of the ABARE export potential for inland New South Wales, which was delivered with more of a fizz than a fanfare in Parkes recently by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Brownhill, telling the inland councils what they knew already—the enormous potential for export from inland New South Wales.

Was it, I wonder, a bit of catching‐up by a government that has failed to support the concept of a fresh food export airport at Parkes, to which over 30 inland New South Wales councils are committed—an inland marketing concept now three years old where the Inland Marketing Corporation has already researched the potential? It did not need ABARE to spell it out for it.

The feasibility study which is now being completed—paid for by Parkes Council, with help from the New South Wales government—is likely to show not only that the inland marketing concept, airport included, is viable, but that it has enormous potential to generate wealth and employment for inland New South Wales, its towns and its farmers alike. Is it any wonder that this government, which reneged on its election commitment to support the study, is furiously trying to catch up and claim some ownership of those statistics when they are published?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDERSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Calare (Mr Andren) for his contribution. As is so often the case, it appears that there are not a lot of people with a great deal of interest in this particular—and I think, vitally important—portfolio and the things that it touches on.

SPEECH.PARA: In the circumstances, I will confine myself to brief remarks about some of the issues that the honourable member raised. He talked about exceptional circumstances and our recent brief extension of some three months of the drought relief payment to those for whom it was to end on 10 June. He indicated that he hoped that the integrated rural policy package would address a wide range of needs.

I want to make the point that the integrated rural package is something that we have been working on for quite a while. It does indeed draw on the work of a large number of reviews but putting the thing together is extraordinarily difficult. On the one hand, we have a responsibility to be compassionate to farm families who cannot meet their needs. On the other hand, we do not want to continue to create an environment in which much of the spirit of resilience, independence and innovation that has made the rural sector in this country so great is undermined. Finding the right balance is not easy.

Let me say at the outset that one of the other major reports that we are drawing on makes it plain that, despite some of the anecdotal evidence to the contrary, there is currently prevailing no failure of availability of farm finance to the rural sector. Businesses that have a future are able to draw on borrowings or on debt equity, if that is the way they choose to finance themselves—and, indeed, having been very closely involved with this portfolio for a long time, I must say that that has been my experience.

It is a welcome change. It is unquestionably different from the situation which prevailed during the times of extraordinarily high interest rates that we saw under the previous regime. I make the point, too, that of far more value than interest rate subsidies—which, of course, we announced in the budget that we would no longer continue with—is a regime under which interest rates fall for everyone.

As a general rule of thumb, only around six per cent of farmers at any given time were receiving interest rate subsidies or business support under normal RAS. It was always difficult to target and it was always hard to make it fair. There were always people who, by the criteria, should probably have been getting assistance but were not, and there were those who were getting assistance but who did not need or deserve that assistance. It is far better to get interest rates down for everyone, to develop a level playing field in which all can have the opportunity to maximise their performance.

In that regard I want to say that, firstly, the government's fiscal consolidation objectives are plainly reaping benefits for farmers, but perhaps they were grossly underestimated. Some people talk a great deal about the $40 million‐odd that went into interest rate subsidies. The interest rates cuts that we have seen since this government came to power just 15 months ago are worth some $350 million to $400 million to the whole of the farm sector. Those cuts are extraordinarily valuable: they are the key to stabilising debt and the key to recovery.

I note with a great deal of pleasure that farm debt in some sectors is now being wound back. Unfortunately, that is not true of the troubled beef sector and, at this stage, it is still not the case in the recovering wool industry. But many other sectors, including grain, appear to be not only starting to reinvest but also winding back debt levels, albeit not at a high rate; nonetheless, that is a very welcome development.

The integrated rural policy package will deal with a wide range of issues, including a more streamlined, equitable and less ad hoc approach to farm welfare. It will also deal more effectively with the business needs of farmers: training, skills, benchmarking, marketing skills and more effective savings mechanisms such as IEDs, farm management bonds and those sorts of things. Finally, let me say that the supermarket to Asia program is an important one. If only it were as simple as being a matter of infrastructure; but it is not. It is about constantly upgrading Australia's approach to food safety, quality, packaging and marketing, if we are to achieve our objective of being a premier supplier of quality foodstuffs to our increasingly able‐to‐pay Asian neighbours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andren, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —At the banking summit in Bathurst last week, a rural councillor gave an example of farmers who were trying to access small business loans at 7.9 per cent being turned away by the major banks and told that in fact they were not a small business. The asset backing these farmers were offering was in terms of land which was close to Sydney and had the potential for subdivision by the banks should they need, down the track, to foreclose—which many have the tendency to do—yet they were asked to pay 11½ per cent overdraft rates and a one per cent service fee. They are also penalised a percentage point now by one major bank because they are under suspicion of having Ovine Johne's disease. If that is an example of supporting the farm sector to try to trade out of difficulty, given that it still has an asset backing, I do not believe that the financial sector is in any way supportive of the rural sector.

SPEECH.PARA: There is one other point I would like to make and that is that any jobs for the dole program, which I would prefer to see called Jobs Australia, should include a farm employment scheme. It should have an adequate training component involving two to three days a week at award rates perhaps, and be aimed at backing up the family farm. Such a program would offer the lone farmer the flexibility he or she needs to climb back to prosperity and get those basic jobs done that are desperately needed, like weed control, that has not been looked at in many months. I am thinking here of some of the serrated tussock problems on the tablelands.

At present, farmers cannot get out on the three‐wheeler to do the work. Apart from the cost of the chemicals, they need the labour assistance. They need that farm help that they once had. They will still be viable if they can get that bit of help. I see this as perhaps one program that the National Farmers Federation and local farming groups could pick up and promote as an idea that can make a positive contribution to the work for the dole program. It will be help the family farm and at the same time soak up some of the 30 per cent plus of the keen, and very skilled in some cases, young, rural unemployed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDERSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)
