TALK.START.PARA: —I would simply like to invite the member for Calare (Mr Andren), if he thinks he has evidence, and I say this in good faith, of banks being unreasonable to farmers, to feel free to approach me on those matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that I would just say that after many years of dealing in this area, knowing it inside out, I say to you to look very closely at the real circumstances in each of these cases. I often have them bowled up to me but when you look at them you find that perhaps their equity is extremely low or that they really have no management system in place, or that perhaps it is not a genuine farming operation. I have to say to you that it is my experience that a farmer who can demonstrate that he or she is competently running a business, that they have some equity left, that they have a prospect of trading, can secure loans that are fully equivalent to, in every way, loans that are offered to the small business sector.

I raise that point because it is very important for farmers to recognise that the old days of great loyalty to banks and expecting that loyalty to be reciprocated and what have you, are gone. Farmers ought to be prepared to bargain. They have to be prepared to shop around. They have to be prepared to thump the table and sell their own case. In those circumstances I think that the overwhelming bulk of farmers today ought to be able to secure loans below 10 per cent. If there is evidence to the contrary, that would be most useful for me as I seek to represent the rural sector. I make that offer in good faith. That wraps up all I had to say.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.

BREAK.PARA: Proposed expenditure, $126,844,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to use this opportunity to raise my concern about some issues that emerged in the budget papers, and most particularly have emerged in the Senate estimates committee consideration of those budget papers. They relate in particular to the relative funding and role of the Office of the Employment Advocate compared to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and what it reflects in terms of the priority of the government in comparing the significance of Australian workplace agreements to awards and other agreements which go through the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: We have in this budget increased resources for the Office of the Employment Advocate and reduced resources for the Industrial Relations Commission. On the face of it there is a budget notation which indicates increased resources for the Industrial Relations Commission to discharge the extra functions that it has achieved as a result of the amalgamation with Victoria. However, as the Senate estimates committee process made clear when questioning the Registrar of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, when, if I can put it in the vernacular, the ons and offs are taken into account, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission is substantially worse off.

The registrar says the net result is about a $300,000 reduction in the running costs appropriation. Given the increased responsibilities of the commission as it relates to the handover in Victoria, that is a cause of concern to me. There was an unwelcome hiatus in the provision of resources to support workers and small business people seeking assistance from what was traditionally done by the Victorian government through Wageline, but I welcome the fact that there is now funding for that. That is, I assume, to be covered by this increased funding, but the cuts that flow with that to the resources of the Industrial Relations Commission make it less able to discharge that obligation.

But I make that comment only as a backdrop. My particular concern is the role of the Office of the Employment Advocate. Of course, everybody knows, I assume, or at least those involved in this debate know, that the opposition's position is essentially that it is an office that should not exist. Half of its function should be performed by the Industrial Relations Commission and could be better done there and some should be done by the department. But that is irrelevant to this discussion. My concern is about the way that it is functioning and about the evidence that is emerging about the Australian workplace agreements for which it is responsible.

The evidence before the estimates committee indicates an organisation operating in a bizarre fashion. I think the Employment Advocate thinks he is actually the Director‐General of ASIO rather than the head of the Office of the Employment Advocate. He has undercover people running around, but only pursuing matters to do with freedom of association. There is no evidence at all of any spot‐check or any activity about any employees concerned about any Australian workplace agreement. He is refusing to disclose to the parliament the most basic information that should be supplied in the interests of accountability to the parliament. He refused to supply the 11 Australian workplace agreements that he has approved, even though we all accept that he would need to delete all the identifying information to conform with the act. There is no argument about that.

BREAK.PARA: But even if you think there is some reason why he might be entitled to refuse that to the parliament—and I do not think there is any—how on earth can he justify refusing to make available the guidelines upon which he is making his decisions? All sorts of cases that have been argued over the years in the various courts and tribunals in Australia have made it clear that taxpayers and citizens are entitled to have access to the guidelines upon which decisions affecting their rights and entitlements are based. Not only is this Employment Advocate not prepared to make them public, he is not prepared even to release them to the parliament. We have this gentleman seeking to run an undercover operation hoping to deny accountability to the parliament in the way that is available only to the nation's security organisations. It is entirely inappropriate. It is an action by a public official the like of which I have not seen before, having had all too many experiences with Senate estimates committees in the past, which I do not miss one bit. But I have never seen anybody behaving in the manner that this gentleman did and it gives me great concern about the way the office is operating. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Industrial Relations; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

TALKER.NAME: Mr REITH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —In regards to the consideration in detail, I would like to respond to a number of the things that the shadow minister has said so that the record is quite clear, particularly in respect of the Office of the Employment Advocate.

SPEECH.PARA: The first general background point he made was that there is something sinister to be derived from an examination of the funding for the Office of the Employment Advocate and the Industrial Relations Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that.
—It is quite clearly sinister, because—
—It is a reflection of priorities.

—Yes, and you then say it is sinister and a reflection of priorities with which you do not agree. But in respect of the funding for the Industrial Relations Commission, clearly, the role of the commission is changing. We have made no secret of that. You talked about its responsibilities. The fact of the matter is that over time you are seeing an evolution where its responsibilities are changing and affecting its workload, not just as a result of the Victorian transfer, but as a result of the operations of the Workplace Relations Act.

SPEECH.PARA: In many areas the commission will have less work than it has had in the past—for example, obviously in respect of unfair dismissals but also in some of the general work that the commission undertakes. But the government continues to support the commission. We continue to ensure that it is appropriately funded. It does have a very important task ahead of it, a task defined by the Workplace Relations Act. One of its essential tasks is to maintain a credible safety net for employees who are reliant upon the award system to provide them with base protections.

There has been no hiatus, shall I say, in the delivery of services in Victoria. We had a seamless transition from the Victorian government's operations to the new Commonwealth operation. By doing so in a very cooperative manner with the Victorian government, we continue to maintain services. Yes, there have been savings there but they come from rationalising the two services into one and I think that is in everybody's interests.

In respect of the operations of the Office of the Employment Advocate, I think it would have been also fair for the shadow minister to put as a background to his comments about the advocate that the Labor Party had been totally opposed to the establishment of the Office of the Employment Advocate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did I say that?

—Everything you say about the advocate is in fact coloured by your views about whether or not we should have an office of employment advocate. For example, you make this extraordinary and, I must say, not becoming comment that you have never seen anything like the performance of the advocate before the Senate committee. In fact, you misrepresented what happened before the Senate committee. He did not say that he was not prepared to produce certain documents. He said that, before he produced anything, he needed to first take legal advice as to what his obligations were under the Workplace Relations Act.

SPEECH.PARA: How can you accuse a public servant of refusing to be accountable to the parliament when what he was saying was that he wants proper legal advice as to what his obligations are? That is what he said. The record is quite clear on that. To say that he is in some way attempting to refuse to participate or to respond to the questions that were put to him is, quite frankly, a gross misrepresentation.

What some of your colleagues in the Senate wanted was the disclosure of Australian workplace agreements when the policy intention of this parliament is quite clear, and that is that that documentation is to be confidential to the parties unless they decide otherwise. I think it is a quite unreasonable attack for you to mount against the advocate. By all means, you may have your disagreements about the Office of the Employment Advocate but why don't you run on those instead of these baseless, silly allegations you have been making? Sure, the unions do not like the fact that the advocate has certain functions given to him by the parliament to enforce the freedom of association provisions of the act, but that is no basis upon which you can mount the sort of attack that you have made.

There was one incident and in that one incident you have also been a party to the union's attack on the advocate. Some of the things have been a complete nonsense. He did not represent himself as a driver's assistant, which the TWU has been going around saying. There were no secretive, underhand tactics, which you have been endorsing out of the comments of the TWU. There was no intention to conceal his identity—that is another baseless allegation that was made. The fact of the matter is that he went to check the veracity of certain allegations made, which is a function the parliament has given him, and he acted legally and in an appropriate manner. So have your disagreements but keep to the facts. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to pursue that issue further, but I would like to take up two matters that were raised by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith). First, I seek information from him because his understanding of a matter of fact is different from mine, and I would be interested if he could give me the information—not necessarily this evening but subsequently—relating to the seamless handover in Victoria. I accept that in some ways that happened, but I have a particular concern with regard to the wage line activities, the information advisory service.

SPEECH.PARA: My understanding from information that was given to me—information that I thought up until now was uncontradicted—is that the Victorian government's wage line activity ceased on 31 March and that the Australian government's activities to replace that did not commence until 1 July because there was no budget appropriation. I understood that to be the case. I have been advised by people who should have known that that was the case. I am not challenging in this instance the minister's word on that. I would be very interested to get the alternative information from him. He may not have it tonight, and it is not a matter of such controversy that I seek it this evening, but I would appreciate his information. It is not an issue of great controversy. I am just interested in the facts of that matter.

With regard to his attack on me about the Employment Advocate, I made it clear this evening that, while I disagree with his view about the making available of Australian workplace agreements, that is a matter on which there is a possibility that there will be some contention. I accept that he has taken legal advice. I think he is wrong, but I accept that there could be some controversy about that.

The question of whether guidelines for decision making should be available to the parliament is a well established matter going back four years. The possibility that they should not be made available seems to me, on the face of it, to be extraordinary. If there is some special circumstance in this matter, I will be fascinated to see what it is.

The point that leads me to rise for a second time is actually the substance of the Australian workplace agreements that are emerging from the shadow of secrecy with which the government tries to drape it. The Employment Advocate—and in this instance I will say to his credit—has before the Senate estimates committee made it absolutely clear that the so‐called rock solid guarantee that no‐one's take‐home pay would be cut is and always was meaningless and is not reflected in this legislation in any way.

What he said quite explicitly and accurately is that you cannot get less than the award which covers your area. I actually think that in the way he is interpreting the act that is not going to be the case, but that is not my point. There will be some evidence about that subsequently and we will deal with that.

But where people have been operating for years and years on the basis of agreements that operate over and above an award the guarantee that they will not lose their take home pay means nothing, because the no disadvantage test operates against the award, which may be hundreds of dollars less than the prior take‐home pay of the employees in question. After hearing the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) say they had a rock solid guarantee that no‐one could cut their take‐home pay, I am sure they would be surprised to find that this is what it means.

We are already finding examples in the 11 Australian workplace agreements that have been approved so far of workers who are substantially—to the tune of hundreds of dollars a fortnight—worse off. This is not denied by the Employment Advocate. He simply says, correctly, that his responsibility is to judge these matters against the award, and he has determined they are not worse off against the award.

In one instance of which I am aware, I do not think he is correct but, as I say, that is not the point I am trying to make this evening. That will take more research before I establish whether I agree with his interpretation, and I will raise that on another occasion. There are many more concerns I have about Australian workplace agreements and about the way they are being reviewed.

I am amazed that up until now in none of the matters which the Employment Advocate has approved has he been in such doubt that he thought any of them needed to be referred to the Industrial Relations Commission for advice with regard to their compliance with the no disadvantage test. I am sure some of them are quite clear, and he gave an example in the Senate estimates which seems, on the face of it, to be quite clear, and there is no reason why he should refer such a case. But that none of them, including the two of which I am aware, created sufficient doubt in his mind to warrant a reference is a source of amazement to me.

BREAK.PARA: I am concerned about the pattern that is emerging of the impact of these Australian workplace agreements on the living standards of Australian men and women working under them. It is a concern I always had about them, and I sadly say it seems to be being borne out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Industrial Relations; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

TALKER.NAME: Mr REITH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —The shadow minister, the member for Canberra (Mr McMullan) is looking for a trend but has no facts upon which to establish it. He says he is absolutely shocked that there has been no case of doubt as yet, but he can only draw from that some sinister inference.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is that—and it is relevant to his second last point—he is entitled to obtain undertakings from parties where he is not satisfied on the face of the documentation. I cannot give you the details of one of the agreements that you have been referring to, but I did notice from Work Force this morning that they claim that further undertakings were given in addition to the documentation, which is quite a nice little point because when you—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are those orders enforceable?

—Yes. It is a nice little point because when you got very excited about what you claim were the first AWAs in Australia being at the casino, firstly, I am told that the first AWAs were not at the casino and, secondly, you did not have all the facts and you did not have all the documentation if Work Force is right. So all I say to you is: by all means, run your arguments, but see if you can get the facts, because you will have a better and more informed debate if you do.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say a few other things. Firstly, the member for Canberra began his speech by saying he would not pursue the issue of the OEA further. I am not sure what he meant by that, seeing we had a few other comments from him, but I am pleased that he said that. He wants some further information on the transfer of the wage line. My memory is that it closed one day and we opened it the next. I note that something was said, I think, in an estimates committee which raised the spectre of a gap. There was no gap, but let me confirm that with the member. That is my genuine understanding of it.

In respect of the evidence that Mr Rowe gave to the Senate estimates committee, I am glad the member for Canberra now says that he accepts that Mr Rowe is taking legal advice. I think he should have said that, in fairness to him, the first time around. The member keeps referring to the guidelines. The fact is that one aspect of this is that they are not concluded guidelines, they are draft guidelines, and at this point in time Mr Rowe personally is approving all of the agreements. So they do not perhaps have the same longer term relevance that they will have once the operation is fully under way.

Finally, the honourable member referred to the guarantee that we gave. The guarantee that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) gave as the Leader of the Opposition in January 1996 was quite explicit: that people would not be disadvantaged against the award. The speech that he gave to the Young Liberals on 8 January is quite explicit. There has never been any question about it. In fact, the only time we had some controversy about it was in a very neat response to say that this was a no‐disadvantage test against the award. In fact, it is the opposition's no‐disadvantage test. By and large, we have made it more flexible and, in a sense, it operates better. Those opposite had a no‐disadvantage test against the award. We have a no‐disadvantage test against the award. I think we have made it a better one in terms of flexibility and the like, but the basic concept has not changed.

Are people entitled to have a no‐disadvantage test against what they were last earning, which was the honourable member's proposition? Our response to that in the 1996 election was: `Well, we're not going to give Paul Keating a guarantee that he'll be earning as much after the election as what he was before the election, because his circumstances will have changed.' The guarantee has always been very clear: a no‐disadvantage test against the award. I do not know why you would find it such a deficient no‐disadvantage test when, for years, you were in fact in support of it.

I conclude by thanking the shadow minister for his contribution. I presume he has completed his remarks. I will be happy to confirm what I have said to him in respect of the seamless transition from Victoria to the Commonwealth in respect of the wage line.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Department of Industry, Science and Tourism

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed expenditure $1,699,412,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In dealing with this area of the budget, I take the opportunity to make a few observations about the recent announcement made by BHP to cease primary steel production in Newcastle in September 1999. BHP established the steelworks in Newcastle in 1915. Since that time Newcastle has become very clearly and very firmly established as a steel producing centre, and the character of Newcastle since that time has always been identified in relation to steel production.

SPEECH.PARA: I think this particular issue illustrates better than most other developments the general attitude of this government to issues of this kind. Steel making is a core activity in Newcastle and is recognised to be so. Despite the fact that BHP proposes to cease primary steel production in September 1999, the response of the government, first of all from the office of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), was that the Prime Minister would hear any submissions in connection with that issue but he would not intervene.

We did not expect the Prime Minister to go to Newcastle and demand that BHP steel production continue. We did not expect that to be the form of intervention. But we did expect the Prime Minister to act as a Prime Minister. The response of the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) was that we have to accept the realities of the world market. The world market is such that the demand for steel is expanding. BHP, as a major Australian corporation, could have taken advantage of that.

Despite the fact that 2,500 people will lose their jobs and 2,500 families will be disadvantaged directly, and in excess of 6,000 individuals and families at least will be disadvantaged indirectly, Mr Moore said, nevertheless, that it was a good day for BHP shares. I did not hear that said, Mr Deputy Speaker, but I have heard it reported; and I have not heard it denied. I am disappointed and disgusted if that was said. It was a good day for BHP shares and for BHP shareholders, and that just shows how crazy this whole position is. Within hours, the value of BHP shares increased by $1 billion as a result of the announcement that it would cease steel making in Newcastle.

In 1983, the Labor government inherited an industrial graveyard in Australia. Industry was inefficient and uncompetitive. The proportion of manufactured goods which we exported was relatively small. During the 13 years that Labor was in government that situation was turned around completely. That was largely as a result of the very dramatic restructuring which took place in the framework of industry in Australia to make it possible for Australian industry to become competitive and to export to a greater extent than it had before.

BREAK.PARA: At that time, in 1983, there was a possibility that primary steel production in Australia would cease altogether. As a result of that, the Labor Party in opposition before 1983 put together what we identified as a steel plan. We said that within 100 days of coming into government the steel plan would be put into operation. It took a little bit longer than 100 days, but it was put into operation. Taxpayers' funds of $90 million went into downstream users of steel. As a result of that, it was possible for us to encourage from BHP a major commitment to continue investment in steel production in Australia. I am pleased to say that, until relatively recently, BHP honoured those commitments.

The decision that BHP has now made was made despite the fact that the former Labor government had a commitment from BHP, as recently as 1995, that it would continue steel production in Newcastle, it would invest $200 million, and it would, if necessary, put in an electric arc furnace in order to ensure that steel production would continue in Newcastle until at least 2002. I will take an opportunity shortly to add further to these remarks. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss, Warren, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take the opportunity offered by the presence of the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr McGauran) at this debate to raise the future of the CSIRO research facility at Narayen near Mundubbera. Mundubbera is in my electorate, but Narayen is actually just across the border in the electorate of Hinkler. This has been a longstanding research station on a very large property watered by a fine river system, and it is certainly an excellent property.

SPEECH.PARA: It has a fine group of buildings, now mostly several decades old, an excellent airstrip and so it is well serviced as a property of quality, and a property which has the capacity to offer a facility for research in a wide variety of areas. It has traditionally been working in pasture research.

Its future has come into question because the Beef Research Committee and, indeed, the beef industry as a whole are suggesting that there are other higher priorities now for industry research than pastures. Many people in the industry disagree with that assessment and believe that it is still very important to the grazing industry for beef producers to have available to them a research facility that can do work on developing the best possible pastures and appropriate management of such pastures.

The facility has also played a major role in the development of the Belmont Red breed of cattle and has been involved in quite a deal of other work. Because the native pastures have been significantly improved as part of the pasture research, even though it is a large property, it has been necessary over recent times to lease some surrounding land to undertake some of their work. But the CSIRO have given no indication at this stage as to what the future of that research facility will be and the staff are naturally anxious about their future. The facility has been steadily wound down over recent years and the staff are also disappointed that the CSIRO has not given them an opportunity to undertake research in other areas. On a number of occasions they have put together proposals to undertake particular activities and these have not been taken up by CSIRO management. So it is not just a matter of the funding coming from industry sources; it is also a question as to whether there is any longer a commitment from the CSIRO to make effective use of this facility.

Even if it is decided that, for one reason or another, there is no longer a future role for pasture research, then the property would have potential for quite a deal of other activities. For instance, it is in one of the most successful citrus growing areas in Australia, perhaps in the world. While there have been problems with the citrus industry in southern states, in the central Burnett the citrus industry has progressed in leaps and bounds, has opened up fantastic new markets in Asia, and has enormous potential. This area could potentially be used for citrus research.

There is also quite a lot of interest in planting vineyards and other small crops, various fruit trees and the like, so the opportunity would be there to use this property for that kind of work. It is a versatile property. As I have mentioned, it is well watered and it has some good quality agricultural land, though it is mainly a grazing property. For all those reasons, it does offer considerable potential for future use for scientific research. The property contributes significantly to its own revenue and could contribute more if it was able to operate on a more commercial basis. Their stud cattle are in high demand, but they could also produce cattle commercially on a much more extensive scale than happens at present.

I am sure that the staff and the people of Mundubbera and Eidsvold would welcome a visit from the minister at some stage—hopefully, fairly soon—so that he can see the property first‐hand. It has a fine airstrip, so he could fly in without delaying his schedule too much. I am sure he would be impressed not only with the quality of the property, but with the dedication of the staff and the way in which they have undertaken their activities. This research facility is very strongly supported by the Mundubbera and Eidsvold communities, their shire councils, the local graziers and the farm organisations, who are all very keen to see its future secured. I would encourage the minister to visit the property soon and to provide a new role for the Narayen research facility to secure its future for the people of the area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address budget paper No. 4, for the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism and the section Grants‐in‐aid, which refers expressly to grants‐in‐aid to the Franchising Code Administration Council. If you look at that expenditure item, you will see that it is precisely zero. That is because this government has withdrawn, from 1996, funding for the Franchising Code Administration Council, the body set up by the previous government to administer the self‐regulatory code of practice established for franchising in 1993.

SPEECH.PARA: After the government withdrew this grant‐in‐aid, the council received legal and accounting advice that it could not be confident of its solvency under the new funding arrangements. It appointed an administrator and ceased trading so in fact it is now out of business. Further to that, the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser) rejected the calls by a parliamentary committee which conducted extensive research into this area for legislation to regulate the franchise sector. The Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs said that, in his view, an industry code of conduct would be the best way to resolve disputes between franchisors and their franchise operators. He further said:
People are missing the fact there are a whole lot of fairly successful franchise operations out there.
The government has got to be mindful not to put in place any arrangement that would in any way disadvantage these successful operations.
The House of Representatives inquiry into fair trading in Australia drew attention to the fact that unfair practices in franchising have been a source of concern for some time.

The inquiry noted that the Franchising Code Council, for the period from May to November of last year, received 123 formal complaints and an additional 2,500 inquiries. We further find that the Franchising Code disputes review received a submission from the Australian Franchisee Association saying that it had taken action against 32 franchisors on behalf of 53 franchisees. Once again that is very strong evidence of the extent of concern in this area.

BREAK.PARA: The committee was able to establish that franchising contracts typically impose very heavy obligations on franchisees, while leaving franchisors' duties relatively undefined. It also points out that the obligations of the franchisor are vital to the franchising relationship and that these contracts, and the fact that franchisees have sunk costs into the venture, necessarily involve the danger of opportunistic abuse. The report states:

The incentive that causes a business with sunk costs to stay in operation despite losses makes franchisees vulnerable to franchisor behaviour known as `opportunism'. Because the franchisee will continue to operate even if it is not recovering its sunk investments, the franchisor can make decisions that induce such losses without the franchisee going out of business. When these decisions benefit the franchisor at the expense of the franchisee, the franchisor opportunistically extracts a portion of the franchisee's sunk costs.

Similarly, the Business Law Committee of the Law Institute of Victoria provided examples of abuses in this area. They include rolling audits of the franchisee to gather evidence of the franchisee's non compliance, and in site specific franchises taking advantage of the franchisee's development of its economic area to force the franchisee to pay goodwill again for its business by threatening to open new stores nearby.

All of these things added up to the committee making a recommendation that the Commonwealth should enact specific franchising legislation, providing for compulsory registration of franchisors and compliance with codes of practice. This is something that the House urgently needs to consider. We need change. If we look at the bankruptcy figures for recent months, we will find that bankruptcy has risen in excess of 20 per cent. The vitality and lifeblood is being drained out of small business. Small businesses in this country are bleeding to death. It is my concern that this is because they have, in the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs, effectively put Dracula in charge of the blood bank.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is almost inconceivable that Australia would be contemplating at the present time the end of primary steel production because that is really what this announcement amounts to. At this point in time, Newcastle is being targeted. There is very little question that Whyalla will follow, and other centres of steel production in Australia could well be in the firing line.

SPEECH.PARA: Some people might think that BHP is no longer investing in steel production. That would be wrong, because BHP is in the process of investing a total package of about $1 billion, but not in Australia. All of that $1 billion is going towards investment in steel production in other countries. All the capital investment is overseas; the job creation is overseas; the technology development is overseas; the development of export potential is overseas; and the infrastructure development is overseas.

The income being generated by the big Australian will be overseas because it has now decided that it is time to abandon Newcastle and the people of Newcastle. As I said, there will be 2,500 jobs lost in the first instance, another 1,500 on‐site contract jobs and at least another 3,000 to 4,000 jobs upon which those people in the rest of Newcastle are dependent will also go—a minimum of about 7,000 jobs; 7,000 workers and 7,000 families affected. BHP said, `We're pulling the plug. We'll invest $1 billion, but we won't invest it here.'

We expect more from the national government. Government is not about sitting on your hands, as this government has been doing, and waiting for BHP to get in touch with you, as the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has said. Leadership is about getting on the phone and calling these people together so that an opportunity can be taken to ask, `What are the options? What can we do? What are your intentions?' That is not what is happening at the present time. The whole thing is an absolute disgrace!

BREAK.PARA: Labor had a steel plan when we came into government in 1983, and it was put into operation. At the time, there were 9,000 employees in steel production in Newcastle. As a result of our steel plan there was a major increase in productivity, which was encouraged and supported admirably by the unions and the work force. From 9,000 people directly involved in steel production in Newcastle the figure has been gradually reduced to what it is at the present time, to about 3,000. Those changes were gradual and were absorbed.

There was an output of about 160 tonnes of steel per employee in Newcastle in 1983. They were told that it had to be 500 tonnes per employee, otherwise steel production could be under threat. They passed through the 500 tonnes target and reached 650 tonnes per employee; it is now about 700 tonnes per employee, and they have been told that if steel production is to continue in Australia it needs to be 1,000 tonnes per employee. We know exactly what the implications of all of this are.

I said it before: government is about taking positive action and taking the initiative. It is also about responding to individual, family and community concerns. Just a week ago we had one of a number of gatherings in Newcastle to which the Prime Minister and the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) were both invited. They sent the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles). I say nothing against the member for La Trobe. He was courageous, and he was treated with every courtesy. But at that meeting we had present the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), the shadow minister for industry, the member for Hotham (Mr Crean), the President of the ACTU, two bishops, four federal Labor members, six state Labor members, the Lord Mayor and over 1,000 citizens. Yet the Prime Minister and the industry minister could not be there: they sent a backbench member of the government, the member for La Trobe—who, as I said, was treated with every courtesy by those people whose future is threatened.

That is the sort of thing that we are getting from this government. That is the sort of thing that the Australian nation is getting from this government. The Australian people are becoming increasingly aware of just what that decision in March of last year meant. I said when I started that Newcastle illustrates it well. Newcastle does illustrate it well, and Newcastle's reaction will illustrate the reaction of the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins, Harry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The contribution that we have just heard from the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) underlines the regional importance of proper industry policy. Those who have studied the Newcastle region know that what is really required is to put in place industry policies that take into account the effect on that region.

SPEECH.PARA: Likewise, although the electorate that I represent is part of metropolitan Melbourne, in the northern suburbs of Melbourne there are two areas where there has been real need and real concern about the direction of this government with regard to industry policy. The areas are, of course, the automotive industry—the passenger vehicle assembly sector—and the textiles, clothing and footwear industry.

If we take the total number of jobs in the northern and western suburbs of Melbourne that are in those two industries, the decisions that are made by government have a great effect in a regional sense. And whilst sometimes that is clouded when you talk about regions within a metropolis like Melbourne, it is still very important.

One of the disappointing aspects of the past 15 months or so of the government is the confusion that we see within this government on industry policy. If we look at the debate that we had over bounties—the backflips that we saw in the shipbuilding bounty, the backflips we saw on the robotic bounty and the backflips on the book bounty—it is of real concern that businesses in those sectors cannot really sit down and plan right through.

Last week I had a meeting, in conjunction with the honourable member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), with some of the people who are involved in the automotive components industries in our two electorates. We had the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean), as the shadow minister, talk to them. One of the things that came out was the relief that they saw now that there had been a decision made in respect of the automotive industries. There was relief that they were able to now sit down and plan for the future. The government has to take into account the psychological effect that the lack of leadership—as the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) has highlighted—has had on industry policy.

There is a need for government, and not only Minister Moore, to really look at industries. For instance, earlier in the year we had decisions made about the pharmaceutical industry, decisions that had to be put in place so that there could be a continuation and certainty in policy decisions by those in the pharmaceutical industry post the factor F scheme.

Whilst there has been put in place some recognition of the importance the pharmaceutical industry has to Australia and there are to be forms of assistance, what this government has lost the plot on is matching industry policy against the effect that the pharmaceutical benefits scheme has on pharmaceutical companies within Australia. At the same time, successive governments, not only the Labor government before this one but the coalition governments before that, put the lid on the price of pharmaceuticals to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. This, of course, has had an effect on the pharmaceutical industry. That has been acknowledged by all.

That was the reason why the elements of the factor F were put in place, so that we could achieve two aims. They were to manage the level of expenditure under the PBS, but also keep a domestic pharmaceutical industry that could be then used for exports. We have had great success in that. That is always what in those dual senses we have to achieve with our policies.

The honourable member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson) has gone to the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology entitled Finding a balance. The discussion of this is of crucial importance to the small business sector which is such a large employer within Australia. At the end of the day what we need to see in industry policy is the emphasis on the employment outcomes.

The emphasis on the employment outcomes is our ability to manufacture here in Australia and to open up export markets so that we can ensure sustainable jobs, especially in the manufacturing industry. If this government is to achieve its aim to have 200,000 new jobs in the manufacturing industry by the year 2000, it has to keep that in mind. It has to protect manufacturing industry's ability to be able to make decisions that will ensure that we continue to achieve export markets. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Mr McGAURAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Technology)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the members for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), Wide Bay (Mr Truss), Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson) and Scullin (Mr Jenkins) for their contributions. The matters raised by the member for Charlton on behalf of his electorate have been well canvassed in the main chamber in recent weeks and will again, no doubt, be raised many times over. In the same vein, the matters surrounding industry policy raised by the member for Scullin also has had much airing in the main chamber. Again, it will be an ongoing debate between the government and opposition.

BREAK.PARA: To set the record right for the member for Charlton, he did quote the Minister for Industry, Science, and Tourism (Mr Moore) as having said, `It was a good day for BHP shares when BHP decided to end steel making at Newcastle.' I have never seen that reported, and I would be more than confident, if not certain, in repudiating it on behalf of the minister. Such a callous disregard for the sensitivities of those directly and indirectly affected by the decision to end steel making in Newcastle is not part of his make‐up.

The other thing the member for Charlton mentioned was the recent rally held in Newcastle at which the government was represented by the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles). May I take the liberty of reminding the member for Charlton of the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism's visit to Newcastle on 19 May. Much of the discussion at that meeting focused on how the federal government's $10 million commitment could be used to create long‐term employment opportunities in the Hunter region. In the same vein, on 29 May the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) met with a delegation of steel workers here at Parliament House, and he expects to be visiting Newcastle soon after his return from overseas, presumably during July.

Turning now to the very interesting and important matter raised by the member for Wide Bay: it is not an unfamiliar issue with me given that he has made strong representations on behalf of Narayen Research Station for a long while now, and in that he is joined by the member for Hinkler (Mr Neville).

It was very fair of the member for Wide Bay to mention the changing nature of research, to the point now where there is a question mark by the beef industry itself whether or not it wants to continue—and especially to the same financial tune—the research conducted at Narayen that previously went on. After all, if industry withdraws its funding, we do have a serious problem at CSIRO in how to make up the shortfall.

I am very interested in some of the alternatives canvassed by the member for Wide Bay. He suggested that the staff are disappointed that some of their innovative proposals for alternative research in different areas has not been taken seriously enough. I certainly undertake for the member for Wide Bay to pursue that with the senior management of CSIRO. We do naturally want to draw on the experience and ideas of the people at Narayen, like any other workplace, for solutions to problems such as this.

He also put forward the possibility of tying in with the dynamic citrus growing region that Narayen is situated within. He also mentioned viticulture and horticulture. They are alternatives which I will direct CSIRO to pursue, if it is not already.

But I do hasten to assure the member for Wide Bay that my earlier commitment to him and to the member for Hinkler will be honoured—which is that there will be no precipitous evacuation of Narayen by CSIRO. Everything is being done in full consultation with the industry and other interested parties. It sounds—if the member for Wide Bay is to be believed entirely, and I see no reason why he should not—as if the staff may not be consulted in the same fashion that other interested parties are, and I will move to rectify that.Thank you for the invitation to visit. I expect to visit Narayen some time in the future but am unable to make a commitment at this time.

The member for Wills who is no longer with us raised the hoary old chestnut of the Franchising Code Council. May I remind the member for Wills, in his absence, that the Franchising Code Council chose to close down itself. Also, in fact, the government increased the funding available to the Franchising Code Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The minister's time has expired, but he can rise again, briefly.

—Thank you. Rather than delay the proceedings of the chamber, I will draw my remarks to a conclusion, again thanking all the members for the vigorous manner in which they expressed their strongly held views.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to indicate my appreciation of the response that was made by the minister and also to assure the minister that I have not found the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism an insensitive person. I did not hear him say that; I did not see it in print. That is widely believed in the Newcastle region that the minister made that response. I hope that if he did not make that response that he will deny it. I will await that denial.

SPEECH.PARA: The $1 billion that the value of BHP shares increased by within hours of that announcement having been made came out of the pockets, out of the food cupboards and off the dinner tables of those 2,500 to 7,000 individuals and families who will lose their jobs in Newcastle as a result of that decision. That is where that increase comes from. It is a direct transfer out of their pockets and out of their budgets straight into the pockets of those people who have shares in BHP.

John Prescott earns $2.23 million every year; he is the boss of BHP. As a result of that decision, his shares went up, within hours, by $1.42 million in value. That is not bad to pick up. Ron McNeily, another top executive in BHP, as a result of that decision, within hours his share value went up by $639,000. Brian Loton did not do too well—his only went up by $146,000. Gerry Ellis's share value went up by almost three‐quarters of a million dollars within hours of the decision being made that increased the value of BHP shares by $1 billion. I repeat: the decision by BHP was that in September 1999 primary steel production in Newcastle will cease, with a direct loss of 2,500 jobs, an indirect loss of another 1,500 on‐site contract jobs, and another 3,000 to 4,000 jobs in the Newcastle area.

I do not suggest for a moment that they made their decision for the purpose of achieving that personal windfall; I do not believe they did. But they achieved the windfall as a result of a decision that they made which was prejudicial in the extreme, not only to Newcastle but to Australian industry, to Australia's future capacity in steel making, and to its position as a major and potentially greater steel exporting nation.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Debate (on motion by Mr Sercombe) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the Main Committee adjourns I would like to make one comment. On behalf of all members of the House I make the point that we are pleased that throughout this debate the relevant ministers have been here for the whole of the debate for each section. I am reliably informed that this is the first time this has happened in some decades.
—Hear, hear!

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: UNESCO Convention: Technical and Vocational Education

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, upon notice, on 18 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the answer to the question No. 2283 (Hansard , 1 June 1995, page 991), is he able to say whether the NSW Government has supported the ratification of the 1989 Unesco Convention on Technical and Vocational Education.
(2) What steps is the Australian Government taking to ratify the Convention.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Schools, Vocational Education and Training; Minister Assisting the Minister for Finance for Privatisation

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The New South Wales Government reserved its position on ratification when the issue was considered by the Australian National Training Authority Ministerial Council on 23 May 1997.

(2) The Australian Government sought advice from all State and Territory Ministers on ratification of the Convention at the meeting of the Australian National Training Authority Ministerial Council on 23 May 1997. It was agreed at that meeting not to ratify the Convention, with New South Wales reserving its position.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 4 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he state that Kirribilli House is supposed to be a residence not of the Prime Minister but for guests of the Commonwealth (Hansard , 15 October 1986, page 2012); if so, does he still hold that view; if not, why not.
(2) Has he approached the Prime Minister to discuss the statement referred to in part (1); if not, why not; if so, what was the Prime Minister's response.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Circumstances have now changed. Kirribilli House is now the home of the Prime Minister and his family.
(2) No. I refer to my answer to the first question.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Social Security: Office Closure and Abolition of Positions

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Martin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 18 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Have positions been abolished or offices closed in the Minister's Department since 2 March 1996; if so, is the Minister able to provide a detailed breakdown of (a) how many jobs and offices have been abolished or closed and (b) which localities are affected.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) During the period 2 March 1996 to 31 March 1997 staffing of the Department of Social Security increased from 19,781 to 20,676 (both full‐time equivalents). However, for a variety of administrative reasons, 464 positions were abolished in this period.

(b) Of the 464 positions that were abolished across the network during the period March 1996 through to March 1997, the majority occurred as a result of staff taking Voluntary Redundancy. However, during this period a total of 109 staff were also able to be redeployed to other positions either within DSS or to other positions within the Australian Public Service. This figure also includes staff transferring from other Departments/Agencies into DSS as a result of redeployment.
The localities affected in respect of jobs abolished are:

ROW.ENTRY: Pacific Central Area Office, Coffs Harbour
South East NSW Area Office, Wollongong
South West NSW Area Office, Queanbeyan
East VIC Area Office, Box Hill

BREAK.PARA: The following changes occurred to the Department's network of offices since 2 March 1996:
Haymarket Regional Office closed 29 November 1996. Staff and functions were transferred to Darlinghurst Regional Office (RO) and Leichhardt RO. The closure was approved by the previous Government.

Boronia Regional Office closed on 29 November 1996 to coincide with the opening of a new office at Glen Waverley. Staff and functions were transferred to Knox RO, Glen Waverley RO and Ferntree Gully RO. The closure was approved by the previous Government.

Bundaberg West DSS Office closed on 15 November 1996 to coincide with the opening of a new and expanded Regional Office in Bundaberg. All staff transferred to the Bundaberg RO. The closure was approved by the previous Government.
Mermaid Beach DSS Office closed on 1 November 1996. Staff and functions were transferred to Southport RO and Palm Beach RO. The closure was approved by the previous Government.
Woodville Regional Office closed on 27 September 1996. Staff and functions were transferred to Port Adelaide RO, Torrensville RO and Kilkenny RO. The closure was approved by the previous Government.
Caulfield Regional Office closed 26 July 1996. Staff and functions were transferred to Oakleigh RO and St Kilda RO. The closure was approved by the previous Government.
Manly Regional Office closed 14 June 1996. Staff and functions were transferred to Dee Why RO. The closure was approved by the previous Government.

Belmont Regional Office closed on 12 April 1996. Staff and functions were transferred to Geelong RO, Corio RO and approximately 8 staff to the Geelong Teleservice Centre. The closure was approved by the previous Government.
Offices opened since 2 March 1996.
Moorabbin Teleservice Spike Centre opened on 2 December 1996.
Adelaide Teleservice Spike Centre opened on 5 May 1997.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 20 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have steps been taken to establish: (a) the Australian Legal Access Forum; (b) the Australian Legal Insurance Taskforce; (c) an Australia-wide jury education program; (d) the National Campaign Against Violence and Crime; and (e) the Human Rights Division of the Federal Court for determining disputes that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission is unable to mediate or conciliate; if not, why not.
(2) Was funding allocated for establishing the programs referred to in part (1) in the 1996-97 Budget; if not why not.
(3) Will funds be allocated for establishing the programs referred to in part (1) in the 1997-98 Budget; if so, what sum.
(4) How many times has each of the programs referred to in part (1) been mentioned by him in the House of Representatives since 2 March 1996.

(5) Did the Government announce during the election of 1996 that it would give Australians a window on the law through the development of innovative software products that will be widely accessible through schools and libraries and legal centres; if so, what steps have been taken.
(6) Was funding allocated for establishing the program referred to in part (5) in the 1996-96 Budget; if not, why not.
(7) How many times has the program referred to in part (5) been mentioned by him in the House of Representatives since 2 March 1996.
(8) Did the Government announce that it would legislate against the export of child pornography; if so, has action been taken; if not, why not.
(9) Has the Government taken steps towards undertaking a statute stocktake program of repair of existing Commonwealth laws; if not, why not.
(10) Has the Government taken steps towards providing support for, and fostering the growth of, restorative justice programs; if not, why not.
(11) Was funding allocated for establishing the programs referred to in part (10) in the 1996-97 Budget; if not, why not.
(12) How many times have the programs referred to in part (10) been mentioned by him in the House of Representatives since 2 March 1996.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) I am committed to the Australian Legal Access Forum and the Government is currently considering proposals by the Law Council of Australia on the scope and timing of such a forum.

(b) I asked the Australian Legal Assistance Board (ALAB) to examine legal expenses insurance schemes in Australia and overseas. In its report, ALAB recognised the significant contribution of the schemes but considered funding and support of these schemes is more appropriately left with the private sector. I am currently considering ALAB's report.
(c) An Australia-wide jury education program has not yet been established.

(d) The National Campaign Against Violence and Crime (NCAVAC) was announced in the 1996/97 Budget and is being developed and implemented by the Office of Law Enforcement Coordination in my portfolio. The NCAVAC represents a strategic approach to crime prevention across Australia, and is being developed in close cooperation with the States and Territories, particularly through the Lead Ministers' National Anti-Crime Strategy Group and its supporting Officers Group. Extensive consultations have already taken place to develop a set of priorities and demonstration projects which will be implemented in partnership with the States and Territories.

(e) After carefully considering this issue, and consulting with the Federal Court, I have decided that the establishment of a Human Rights Registry in the Federal Court, in conjunction with the use of judicial registrars, is a better option. Separate Divisions can impact adversely on management flexibility within the Court. It would also be difficult to justify the creation of a separate Division of the Court for human rights matters when there are no separate arrangements for other significant and much larger workload areas in the Court, such as trade practices and commercial work.

Creation of a Human Rights Registry acknowledges the mainstream nature of human rights matters, yet enables the Court to develop user friendly procedures and separate listing arrangements to facilitate handling of human rights cases. The expected caseload means that, at this stage, registry facilities for human rights matters will be co-located with existing registry facilities. However, the Court advises that its registry staff will be receiving appropriate training to deal with human rights cases. Consultations with the Court are underway about the introduction of special procedures and registry facilities for human rights cases.

(2) (a) No funding was allocated in the 1996-97 budget for the Australian Legal Access Forum. I am still considering the views of the Law Council of Australia about the Forum proposals and will address potential funding needs when I have had the opportunity to consider these proposals further.

(b) No funding was allocated in the 1996-97 budget for the Australian Legal Insurance Taskforce. I am still considering the views of the Australian Legal Assistance Board about the Taskforce proposals and will address potential funding needs when I have had the opportunity to consider these proposals further.
(c) No funding was allocated in the 1996-97 budget to establish an Australia-wide jury education program.
(d) The Government allocated $4.4m to the NCAVAC for 1996/97.

(e) No funding was allocated in the 1996-97 budget for a Human Rights Division in the Federal Court. As there will be no new Division in the Court, and due to the expected caseload, existing court registry facilities will be used for human rights matters.
(3) (a) No funding has been allocated in the 1997-98 budget for the Australian Legal Access Forum.
(b) No funding has been allocated in the 1997-98 budget for the Australian Legal Insurance Taskforce.
(c) No funding has been allocated in the 1997-98 budget to establish an Australia-wide jury education program.
(d) Approximately $4m will be allocated to the National Campaign Against Violence and Crime in 1997/98.
(e) No funding has been allocated in the 1997-98 budget for a Human Rights Division in the Federal Court.
(4) This information is available from the House of Representatives Hansards which can be examined via the Parliamentary Database Service.

(5) Yes. A program entitled `Window on the Law' was announced by the Government in the Law and Justice For Us All policy statement issued prior to the March 1996 election. The objectives of the program are as set out in the question.

A number of steps have been taken to implement these objectives. First, all Commonwealth legislation has been consolidated in electronic form. Second, that material (together with other Commonwealth caselaw and State and Territory legislation and caselaw from the Attorney-General's Department's SCALEplus system) has been made available free to air for all Australian schools, libraries and legal centres and the general public from an internet service operated by the Australian Government Publishing Service (AGPS). SCALEplus has been available from 1 January 1997 and statistics of use are showing wide acceptance with, typically, more than 4,000 daily `hits' being recorded on this site. The formal launch of `Window on the Law' is to be held in the near future.

`Window on the Law' will be an internet-based, free to air service which will provide Australians, schools, libraries and any organisations with internet access to: an overview of the legal system in Australia; and a gateway to SCALEplus, with access to Commonwealth legislation and other legal data.
(6) `Window on the Law' objectives are being achieved through a reprioritisation of recurrent funds within my Department.
(7) This information is available from the House of Representatives Hansards which can be examined via the Parliamentary Database Service.

(8) On 9 July 1996, the Government announced that it would legislate to prohibit the export of all refused classification materials, including child pornography, to ensure that export regulations are consistent with import regulations. The announcement followed the Government's pre-election commitment to legislate to prohibit the export of child pornography.

Regulation 4A of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations prohibits the importation of a category of publications and other goods which is defined to include child pornography. This regulation is administered by the Attorney-General.
The Minister Responsible for Customs, the Hon Geoff Prosser MP, is responsible for those provisions of the Customs Act which deal with prohibited exports.

In consultation with the Attorney-General, the Minister Responsible for Customs is seeking amendment of the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations to make those regulations mirror regulation 4A of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations.

The Australian Customs Service, in consultation with the Attorney‐General's Department, has issued drafting instructions to the Office of Legislative Drafting within that Department in order to implement the necessary legislative changes. The draft regulations are at an advanced stage and are currently being settled by the relevant agencies.

(9) The Government has commenced the statute stocktake. As stated in More Time for Business, the Government's response to the Small Business Deregulation Task Force, I have written to Ministers requesting that Departments advise the Office of Parliamentary Counsel of redundant Acts for repeal, and that Ministers set priorities for repair of existing legislation. These measures complement the Commonwealth's Legislation Review Schedule, the review of legislation costly to business or restricting competition, announced by the Treasurer on 28 June 1996.

(10) The Government is awaiting the findings of research being conducted by Professor John Braithwaite at the ANU into the ACT Reintegrative Shaming Experiment (RISE project) being conducted in association with the Australian Federal Police. In addition, the Australasian Police Ministers' Council has been reviewing the range of such programs operating in different jurisdictions.
(11) No funding was allocated in the 1996-97 budget to establish restorative justice programs.
(12) This information is available from the House of Representatives Hansards which can be examined via the Parliamentary Database Service.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Martin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 13 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the defence efficiency review headed by Dr M McIntosh report in April 1997 that 8000 jobs are to disappear from the Australian Defence Force.
(2) If so, in which cities, suburbs, towns or regions are those jobs currently located.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McLachlan, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The Defence Efficiency Review identified 4,700 Australian Defence Force positions in administration and support areas to be saved. About half of these will be redirected to combat and combat support areas of the Australian Defence Force. In addition, a further 7,000 Australian Defence Force positions will be subject to market testing. The final number of Australian Defence Force positions that will be saved cannot be known until these processes are complete. In addition, 3,400 civilian positions in the Defence Organisation are expected to be saved, and a further 5,900 will be subject to market testing.

(2) All States and mainland Territories will be affected by the findings of the Review. The Review did not identify the location of positions to be saved or tested in the level of detail sought by the honourable member.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 13 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a speech given by Mr G Samuel, newly appointed President of the National Competition Council on 23 April 1997 in which he spoke about the need for a revolution in health care.
(2) Is the Government considering a quasi voucher system for patients; if so, when will the system be introduced.
(3) Has he met with Mr Samuel to discuss health policy since Mr Samuel's appointment as President of the National Competition Council.
(4) Is he able to say whether Mr Samuel holds or has held positions within the Liberal Party's Victorian Division.
(5) Is he able to say whether Mr Samuel holds a position within the Victorian health system.
(6) Is he also able to say whether Mr Samuel played a role in the decision to close Burwood Hospital in Victoria.
(7) Has he had discussions with Mr Samuel in regard to the closure of Burwood Hospital; if so, when.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. Inquiries to Mr Samuel's office indicate that his speech was largely about AFL football.
(5) Mr Samuel is the Chairman of the Inner and Eastern Health Care Network, Melbourne Metropolitan Health Care Services.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mossfield, Frank, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 13 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Adult Migrant English Program (AMEP) being left to tender; if so, what savings will be or are being achieved.
(2) Do suitable service efficiency comparisons exist between the existing Adult Migrant Education Service and other organisations.
(3) Will the tendering process open up more places for clients needing access to the AMEP.

(4) Has his attention been drawn to claims made in the House of Representatives (Hansard , 12 November 1992, page 3327) that direct funding provided by his Department was 38% cheaper than through competitive tendering; if so, what has occurred to change this situation.
(5) What steps are being taken to ensure that ethnic community groups and migrants will not be confused by a multiplicity of service providers which may result from the tendering process.
(6) Will the tendering process result in a change to a user pays system instead of a free service to migrants or will the new system generate sufficient funds to maintain the free service.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Adult Migrant English Program (AMEP) is being tendered, as I foreshadowed in my announcement of 20 August 1996. The process of selecting AMEP service providers through competitive tendering is currently nearing completion in Victoria and Western Australia and will shortly begin in other States and Territories. New contracts are scheduled to be in place nationally by July 1998.

The Government believes that implementing tendering for the AMEP will deliver a better service to clients, including better access and improved learning outcomes, for example through greater flexibility of learning arrangements, client choice of provider and partnerships between service providers and community agencies. While ensuring best value for money is an important consideration in tendering the Program, the primary objective in subjecting the market to competition is to achieve improvements to program delivery for clients.

(2) Benchmarks are being developed by the National Centre for English Teaching and Research (NCELTR) at Macquarie University which will allow comparison of outcomes across all AMEP service providers nationally. The benchmarks provide predictions of AMEP clients' likely learning achievement against the number of hours they spend in the AMEP, taking account of factors such as the client's literacy in own language, use of roman or non-roman script and age.

(3) Tenderers for AMEP services are required to adopt measures to increase AMEP reach, that is the percentage of eligible clients who access the service. It is expected that this requirement, with the additional flexibility made possible through tendering, will lead to more clients taking up their AMEP entitlement.

(4) In 1992 I commented on the comparative costs of English language programs delivered by the (then) Departments of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Employment, Education and Training. Such comparisons have little application today as the English as a Second Language industry has changed significantly, including through the development of new high quality public and private sector providers.

(5) Currently the AMEP is delivered by a range of agencies: Adult Migrant English Service (AMES) and University of NSW in NSW, AMES, Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology (RMIT) and Northern Metropolitan Institute of TAFE (NMIT) in Victoria, AMES in South Australia and Tasmania, TAFE in Queensland and WA, Northern Territory University in the Northern Territory and

the Canberra Institute of Technology in the ACT. My Department has put into place strategies including community consultations to ensure that ethnic community groups and migrants are aware of the additional choices which tendering is expected to offer AMEP clients. Further information will be provided to the community when decisions are made on service providers following completion of the tender processes.

(6) Migrants in the skilled categories who do not have functional English are required to pay a charge before visa issue. Preferential Family and Refugee/Humanitarian entrants are exempt from the charge. The tendering process will not lead to changes in the user pays system.
